div.head: To the truly noble, by all titles, sir Francis Stuart:
div.p: My hope is not so nourished by example, as it will conclude, this dumb piece should please you, by cause it hath pleased others before: but by trust, that when you have read it, you will find it worthy to have displeased none. This makes, that I now number you, not only in the names of favour, but the names of justice, to what I write; and do, presently, call you to the exercise of that noblest, and manliest virtue: as coveting rather to be freed in my fame, by the authority of a judge, than the credit of an undertaker. Read therefore, I pray you, and censure. There is not a line, or syllable in it changed from the simplicity of the first copy. And, when you shall consider, through the certain hatred of some, how much a man's innocency may be endangered by an uncertain accusation; you will, I doubt not, so begin to hate the iniquity of such natures, as I shall love the contumely done me, whose end was so honourable, as to be wiped off by your sentence.

closer.signed: Your unprofitable, but true lover, Ben Jonson.

list.item: Morose,a gentleman that loves no noise.
Epicoene,a young gent. supposed the silent woman.
Thom. Otter,a land, and sea captain.

lg.l: Truth says, of old, the art of making plays
Was to content the people; and their praise
Was to the poet money, wine, and bays.
But in this age, a sect of writers are,
That, only, for particular likings care,
And will taste nothing that is popular.
With such we mingle neither brains, nor breasts;
Our wishes, like to those (Make public feasts)
Are not to please the cooks tastes, but the guests.
Yet, if those cunning palates hither come,
They shall find guests entreaty, and good room;
And though all relish not, sure, there will be some,
That, when they leave their seats, shall make 'em say,
Who wrote that piece, could so have written a play:
But that, he knew, this was the better way.
For, to present all custard, or all tart,
And have no other meats, to bear a part,
Or to want bread, and salt, were but course art.
The poet prays you then, with better thought
To sit; and, when his cates are all in brought,
Though there be none far fetched, there will dear-bought
Be fit for ladies: some for lords, knights, squires,
Some for your waiting wench, and city-wires,
Some for your men, and daughters of whitefriars.
Nor is it, only, while you keep your seat
Here, that his feast will last; but you shall eat
A week at ordinaries, on his broken meat:
If his muse be true,
Who commends her to you.
The ends of all, who for the scene do write,
Are,Occasioned by some persons impertinent exception.or should be, to profit, and delight.
And still 't hath been the praise of all best times,
So persons were not touched, to tax the crimes.
Then, in this play, which we present tonight,
And make the object of your ear, and sight,
On forfeit of yourselves, think nothing true,
Lest so you make the maker to judge you.
For he knows, poet never credit gained
By writing truths, but things (Like truths) well feigned.
If any, yet, will (With particular slight
Of application) wrest what he doth write;
And that he meant or him, or her, will say:
They make a libel, which he made a play.

sp.p: He comes out making himself ready.have you got the song yet perfect I ga' you, boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You shall, sir, but i'faith let nobody else.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, I pay?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
It will get you the dangerous name of a poet in
town, sir, besides me a perfect deal of ill will at the mansion you wot of, whose lady is the argument of it: where now I am the welcomest thing under a man that comes there.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I think, and above a man too, if the truth were racked out of you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No faith, I'll confess before, sir. The gentlewomen play with me, and throw me of the bed; and carry me into my lady; and she kisses me with her oiled face; and puts a peruke of my head; and asks me an● I will wear her gown; and I say, no: and then she hits me a blow of the ear, and calls me innocent, and lets me go.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No marvel, if the door be kept shut against your master, when the entrance is so easy to you — well sir, you shall go there no more, lest I be fain to seek your voice in my lady's rushes, a fortnight hence, sing, sir. Boy sings.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, here's the man that can melt away his time, and never feels it! what, between his mistress abroad, and his ingle at home, high fare, soft lodging, fine clothes, and his fiddle; he thinks the hours ha' no wings, or the day no post-horse. Well, sir gallant, were you struck with the plague this minute, or condemned to any capital punishment tomorrow, you would begin then to think, and value every article of your time, esteem it at the true rate, and give all for't.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, what should a man do?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, nothing: or that, which when 'tis done, is as idle. Harken after the next horse-race, or hunting-match; lay wagers, praise puppy, or peppercorn, whitefoot, franklin;Horses of the time.swear upon White-maine's party; sp●nd aloud, that my lords may hear you; visit my ladies at night, and be able to give 'em the character of every bowler, or better of the green. These be the things, wherein your fashionable men exercise themselves, and I for company.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Nay, if I have thy authority, I'll not leave yet. Come, the other are considerations, when we come to have grey heads, and weak hams, moist eyes, and shrunk members.
we think she sleeps: nor, when the doors are shut, should men be enquiring, all is sacred within, then. Is it for us to see their perukes put on, their false teeth, their complexion, their eyebrows, their nails? you see guilders will not work, but enclosed. They must not discover, how little serve, with the help of art, to adorn a great deal. How long did the canvas hang afore Aldgate? were the people suffered to see the city's love, and charity, while they were rude stone, before they were painted, and burnished? No. No more should servants approach their mistresses, but when they are complete, and finished.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well said, my True-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And a wise lady will keep a guard always upon the place, that she may do things securely. I once followed a rude fellow into a chamber, where the poor madam, for haste, and troubled, snatched at her peruke, to cover her baldness: and put it on, the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O prodigy!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And the unconscionable knave held her in compliment an hour, with that reversed face, when I still looked when she should talk from the tother side.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, thou shouldst ha' relieved her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No faith, I let her alone, as we'll let this argument, if you please, and pass to another, when saw you Dauphine, Eugenie?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not these three days. Shall we go to him this morning? he is very melancholic, I hear.

sp.speaker: Tru
sp.p: Sick of the uncle? is he? I met that stiff piece of formality, his uncle, yesterday, with a huge turban of nightcaps on his head, buckled over his ears.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, that's his custom when he walks abroad. He can endure no noise, man.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
So I have heard. But is the disease so ridiculous in him, as it is made? they say, he has been upon divers treaties with the fishwives, and orenge-women; and articles
propounded between them: marry, the chimney-sweepers will not be drawn in.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, nor the broom-men: they stand out stiffly. He cannot endure a costard-monger, he swoons if he hear one.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: methinks , a smith should be ominous.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Or any hammer-man. A brazier is not suffered to dwell in the parish, nor an armourer. He would have hanged a pewterer's apprentice once up on a Shrove-tuesday riot, for being of that trade, when the rest were quit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A trumpet should fright him terribly, or the oboes?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Out of his senses. The weights of the city have a pension of him, not to come near that ward. This youth practised on him, one night, like the bellman; and never left till he had brought him down to the door, with a long-sword: and there left him flourishing with the air.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, sir! he hath chosen a street to lie in, so narrow at both ends, that it will receive no coaches, nor carts, nor any of these common noises: and therefore, we that love him, devise to bring him in such as we may, now and then, for his exercise, to breathe him. He would grow resty else in his ease. His virtue would rust without action. I entreated a bearward, one day, to come down with the dogs of some four parishes that way, and I thank him, he did; and cried his games under master Morose's window: till he was sent crying away, with his head made a most bleeding spectacle to the multitude. And, another time, a fencer, marching to his prize, had his drum most tragically run thorough, for taking that street in his way, at my request.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A good wag. How does he for the bells?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
O, i' the Queen's time, he was wont to go out of town every Saturday at ten o'clock , or on holy-day-eves. But now, by reason of the sickness, the perpetuity of ringing has made him devise a room, with double walls, and
treble feelings; the windows close shut, and called: and there he lives by candlelight. He turned away a man last week, for having a pair of new shoes, that creaked. And this fellow waits on him now, in tennis-court socks, or slippers soled with wool: and they talk each to other, in a trunk. See who comes here.
How now! what all you sirs? dumb?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Struck into stone almost, I am here, with tales of thine uncle! There was never such a prodigy heard of.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I would you would once lose this subject, my masters, for my sake. They are such as you are, that have brought me into that predicament, I am, with him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Marry, that he will disinherit me, no more. He thinks, I, and my company are authors of all the ridiculous acts, and monuments are told of him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Slid, I would be the author of more, to vex him, that purpose deserves it: it gives thee law of plaguing him. I'll tell thee what I would do. I would make a false almanac; get it printed: and then ha' him drawn out on a coronation day to the tower-wharf, and kill him with the noise of the ordinance. Disinherit thee! he cannot, man. Art not thou next of blood, and his sister's son?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I but he will thrust me out of it, he vows, and marry.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How! that's a more portent. Can he endure no noise, and will venture on a wife?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes: why, thou art a stranger, it seems, to his best trick, yet. He has employed a fellow this half year, all over England, to hearken him out a dumb woman; be she of any form, or any quality, so she be able to bear children: her silence is dowry enough, he says.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But, I trust to God, he has found none.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, but he has heard of one that's lodged i' the next street to him, who is exceedingly soft-spoken; thrifty of her speech; that spends but six words a day. And her he's about now, and shall have her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Is't possible! who is his agent i' the business?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Marry, a barber, one Cutberd: an honest fellow, one that tells Dauphine all here.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, you oppress me with wonder! A woman, and a barber, and love no noise!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes faith. The fellow trims him silently, and has not the knack with his shears, or his fingers: and that continence in a barber he thinks so eminent a virtue, as it has made him chief of his counsel.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Is the barber to be seen? or the wench?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Y●●, that they are.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I pray thee, Dauphine, let's go thither.

sp.speaker: Daup
sp.p: I have some business now: I cannot i' faith.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You shall have no business shall make you neglect this, sir, we'll make her talk, believe it; or if she will not, we can give out, at least so much as shall interrupt the treaty: we will break it. Thou art bound in conscience, when he suspects thee without cause to torment him.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Not I, by any means. I ll give no suffrage to 't. He shall never ha' that plea against me, that I opposed the least fantasy of his. Let it lie upon my stars to be guilty, I'll be innocent.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, and be poor, and beg; do, innocent: when some groom of his has got him an heir, or this barber, if he himself cannot. Innocent! I pray thee, Ned, where lies she? let him be innocent, still.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, right over against the barbers; in the house, where sir John Daw lies.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You do not mean to confound me!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Does he, that would marry her, know so much?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Excellent! He was a fine youth last night, but now he is much finer! what is his christen-name? I ha' forgotten.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Si amorous La-foole.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The gentleman is here below, that owns that name.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Heart, he's come, to invite me to dinner, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Like enough: pray thee, let's ha' him up.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Boy, marshal him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: With a truncheon, sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A way, I beseech you. I'll make him tell us his pedigree, now; and what meat he has to dinner; and, who are his guests; and, the whole course of his fortunes: with a breath.
'Save, dear sir Dauphine, honoured master Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sir amorous! you have very much honested my lodging, with your presence.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Good faith it is a fine lodging! almost, as delicate a lodging, as mine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not so, sir.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Excuse me, sir, if it were i'the strand, I assure you. I am come, master Clermont, to entreat you wait upon two or three ladies, to dinner, today.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How, sir! wait upon 'em? did you ever see me carry dishes?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No, sir, dispense with me; I meant, to bear 'em company.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, that I will, sir. The doubtfulness of your phrase, believe it, sir, would breed you a quarrel, once an hour, with the terrible boys, if you should but keep 'em fellowship a day.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: It should be extremely against my will, sir, if I contested with any man.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I believe it, sir; where hold you your feast?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: At Tom otters, sir.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Tom Otter? what's he?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Captain Otter, sir; he is a kind of gamester: but he has had command, both by sea, and by land.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: O, than he is animal amphibium?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Ay, sir: his wife was the rich china-woman, that the courtiers visited so often, that gave the rare entertainment. She commands all at home.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then, she is captain Otter?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: You say very well, sir: she is my kinswoman, a la-foole by the mother side, and will invite, any great ladies, for my sake.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Not of the La-fooles of Essex?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No, sir, the La-fooles of London.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now, he's in.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p:
They all come out of our house, the La-fooles of the North, the La-fooles of the West, the La-fooles of the East, and South — we are as ancient a family, as any is in Europe — but I myself am descended lineally of the French La-fooles — and, we do bear for our coat yellow, or or, chequered azure, and gules, and some three or four colours more, which is a very noted coat, and has, sometimes been solemnly worn by divers nobility of our house — but let that go, antiquity is not respected now — I had a brace of fat does sent me gentlemen, and half a dozen of pheasants, a dozen or two of God wits, and some other fowl, which I would have eaten, while they are good, and in good company — there will be a great lady, or two, my lady haughty, my lady centaur, mistress Dol Mavis — and they come a'purpose, to see the silent gentlewoman, mistress Epicoene, that honest sir John Daw has promised to bring thither — and then, mistress trusty, my lady's woman, will be there too, and this honourable
knight, sir Dauphine, with yourself, master Clerimont — and we'll be very merry, and have fiddlers, and dance — I have been a mad wag, in my time, and have spent some crowns since I was a page in court, to my lord lofty, and after, my lady's gentleman-usher, who got me knighted in Ireland, since it pleased my elder brother to die — I had as fair a gold jerkin on that day, as any was worn in the island-voyage, or at Caliz, none dispraised, and I came over in it hither, showed myself to my friends, in court, and after went down to my tenants, in the country, and surveyed my lands, let new leases, took their money, spent it in the eye of the land here, upon ladies — and now I can take up at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Can you take up ladies, sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, let him breathe, he has not recovered.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Would I were your half, in that commodity —

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No, sir, excuse me: I meant money, which can take up any thing. I have another guest, or two, to invite, and say as much to, gentlemen. I'll take my leave abruptly, in hope you will not fail — your servant.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: We will not fail you, sir precious la-foole; but she shall, that your ladies come to see: if I have credit, afore sir daw.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Did you ever hear such a wind-sucker, as this?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Or, such a rook, as the other! that will betray his mistress, to be seen. Come, 'tis time, we prevented it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Go.

Cannot I, yet, find out a more compendious method, then by this trunk, to save my servants the labour of speech, and mine ears, the discord of sounds? Let me see: all discourses, but mine own, afflict me, they seem harsh,
impertinent, and irksome. Is it not possible, that thou shouldst answer me, by signs, and, I apprehend thee, fellow? speak not, though I question you. You have taken the ring, off from the street door, as I bade you? answer me not, by speech, but by silence; unless,At the breaches, still the fellow makes legs, or signsit be otherwise (—) very good. And, you have fastened on a thick quilt, or flock-bed, on the outside of the door; that if they knock with their daggers, or with brickbats, they can make no noise? but with your leg, your answer, unless it be otherwise (—) very good. This is not, only, fit modesty in a servant, but good state, and discretion in a master. And you have been with Cutberd, the barber, to have him come to me? (—) good. And, he will come presently? answer me not but with your leg, unless it be otherwise: if it be otherwise, shake your head, or shrug (—) so. Your Italian, and Spaniard, are wise in these! and it is a frugal, and comely gravity. How long will it be, ere Cutberd come? stay, if an hour, hold up your whole hand; if half an hour, two fingers; if a quarter, one; (—) good: half a quarter? 'tis well. And have you given him a key, to come in without knocking? (—) good. And, is the lock oiled, and the hinges, today? (—) good. And the quilting of the stairs nowhere worn out, and bore (—) very good. I see, by much doctrine, and impulsion, it may be effected: stand by. The Turk, in this divine discipline, is admirable, exceeding all the potentates of the earth; still waited on by mutes; and all his commands so executed; yea, even in the war (As I have heard) and in his marches, most of his charges, and directions, given by signs, and with silence: and exquisite art! and I am heartily ashamed, and angry oftentimes, that the princes of Christendom, should suffer a barbarian, to transcend 'em in so high a point of felicity. I will practise it, hereafter. How now? o! o! what villain? what prodigy of mankind is that? look. Oh! One winds a horn without. Again.cut his throat, cut his throat: what murderer, hellhound, devil can this be?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: It is a post from the court —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Out rogue, and must thou blow thy horn, too?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Alas, it is a post from the court, sir, that says, he must speak with you, pain of death —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pain of thy life, be silent.

div.head: Act ii. scene ii.

sp.p: By your leave, sir (I am a stranger here) is your name, master Morose? is your name, master Morose? Fishes! Pythagoreans all! this is strange! What say you, sir, nothing? Has Harpocrates been here, with his club, among you? well sir, I will believe you to be the man, at this time: I will venture upon you, sir. Your friends at court commend 'em to you, sir —

div.stage: (Mor. oh men! O manners! was there ever such an impudence?)

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And are extremely solicitous for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Whose knave are you!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Mine own knave, and your compeer, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Fetch me my sword —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You shall taste the one half of my dagger, if you do (Groom) and you, the other, if you stir, sir: be patient, I charge you, in the King's name, and hear me without insurrection. They say, you are to marry? to marry! do you mark, sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How then, rude companion!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Marry, your friends do wonder, sir, the Thames being so near, wherein you may drown so handsomely; or London-bridge, at a low fall, with a fine leap, to hurry you down the stream; or, such a delicate steeple, i' the town, as bow, to vault from; or, a braver height, as Paul's, or, if you affected to do it nearer home, and a shorter way, an excellent garret window, into the street; or, a beam, in the said
garret, with this halter; which they have sent, and desire,He shows him a halterthat you would sooner commit your grave head to this knot, then to the wedlock noose; or, take a little sublimate, and go out of the world, like a rat; or a fly (As one said) with a straw i' your arse: any way, rather, than to follow this goblin matrimony. Alas, sir, do you ever think to find a chaste wife, in these times? now? when there are so many masques, plays, Puritan preachings, mad-folks, and other strange fights to be seen daily, private and public? if you had lived in King Etheldred's time, sir, or Edward the confessors, you might, perhaps have found in some cold country-hamlet, then, a dull frosty wench, would have been contented with one man: now, they will as soon be pleased with one leg, or one eye. I'll tell you, sir, the monstrous hazards you shall run with a wife.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Good sir! have I ever cozened any friends of yours of their land? bought their possessions? taken forfeit of their mortgage? begged a reversion from 'em? bastarded their issue? what have I done, that may deserve this?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nothing, sir, that I know, but your itch of marriage.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why? if I had made an assassinate upon your father; vitiated your mother; ravished your sisters —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I would kill you, sir, I would kill you, if you had.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why? you do more in this, sir: it were a vengeance centuple, for all facinorous acts, that could be named, to do that you do —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Alas, sir, I am but a messenger: I but tell you, what you must hear. It seems, your friends are careful after your soul's health, sir, and would have you know the danger (But you may do your pleasure, for all them, I persuade not, sir) if, after you are married, your wife do run away with a vaulter, or the Frenchman that walks upon ropes, or him that dances the jig, or a fencer for his skill at his weapon, why it is not their fault; they have discharged their consciences: when you know what may happen. Nay,
suffer valiantly, sir, for I must tell you, all the perils that you are obnoxious too. If she be fair, and young, vegetous, no sweetmeats ever drew more flies; all the yellow doublets, and great roses i' the town will be there. If foul, and crooked, she'll be with them, and buy those doublets and roses, sir. If rich, and that you marry her dowry, not her; she'll reign in your house, as imperious as a widow. If noble, all her kindred will be your tyrants. If fruitful, as proud as may, and humorous as April; she must have her doctors, her midwives, her nurses, her longings every hour: though it be for the dearest morsel of man. If learned, there was never such a parrot; all your patrimony will be too little for the guests, that must be invited, to hear her speak Latin and Greek: and you must lie with her in those languages too, if you will please her. If precise, you must feast all the silenced brothers, once in three days; salute the sisters; entertain the whole family, or wood of 'em; and hear long-winded exercises, singings, and catechisings, which you are not given to, and yet must give for: to please the zealous matron your wife, who, for the holy cause, will cozen you, over and above. You begin to sweat, sir? but this is not half, i'faith: you may do your pleasure notwithstanding,The mute is stealing away.as I said before, I come not to persuade you. Upon my faith, master servingman, if you do stir, I will beat you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, what is my sin! what is my sin?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Then, if you love your wife, or rather, dote on her, sir: oh, how she'll torture you! and take pleasure i' your torments! you shall lie with her but when she lists; she will not hurt her beauty, her complexion: or it must be for that jewel, or that pearl, when she does; every half hour's pleasure must be bought anew: and with the same pain, and charge, you wooed her at first. Then, you must keep what servants she please; what company she will; that friend must not visit you without her licence; and him she loves most she will seem to hate eagerliest, to decline your
jealousy; or, feign to be jealous of you first; and for that cause go live with her she-friend, or cousin at the college, that can instruct her in all the mysteries, of writing letters, corrupting servants, taming spies; where she must have that rich gown for such a great day; a new one for the next; a richer for the third; be served in silver; have the chamber filled with a succession of grooms, footmen, ushers, and other messengers; besides embroiderers, jewellers, tire-woman, sempsters, feathermen, perfumers; while she feels not how the land drops away; nor the acres melt; nor foresees the change, when the mercer has your woods for her velvets; never weighs what her pride costs, sir: so she may kiss a page, or a smooth chin, that has the despair of a beard; be a states-woman, know all the news, what was done at Salisbury, what at the bath, what at court, what in progress; or, so she may censure poets, and authors, and styles, and compare 'em, Daniel with Spenser, Johnson with the tother youth, and so forth; or, be thought cunning in controversies, or the very knots of divinity; and have, often in her mouth, the state of the question: and then skip to the mathematics, and demonstration and answer, in religion to one; in state, to another, in bawdry to a third.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, o!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: All this is very true, sir. And then her going in disguise to that conjurer, and this cunning woman: where the first question is, how soon you shall die? next, if her present servant love her? next that, if she shall have a new servant? and how many? which of her family would make the best bawd, male, or female? what precedence she shall have by her next match? and sets down the answers, and believes 'em above the scriptures. Nay, perhaps she'll study the art.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Gentle sir, ha' you done? ha' you had your pleasure of me? I'll think of these things.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes sir: and then comes reeking home of vapour and sweat, with going afoot, and lies in, a month, of a new face, all oil, and birdlime; and rises in ass's milk, and is cleansed with a new fucus: God b'w'you, sir. One thing more (Which I had almost forgotten.) This too, with whom you are to marry, may have made a conveyance of her virginity aforehand, as your wise widows do of their states, before they marry, in trust to some friend, sir: who can tell? or if she have not done it yet, she may do, upon the wedding day, or the night before, and antedate you cuckold. The like has been heard of, in nature. 'tis no devised impossible thing, sir. God b'w'you: I'll be bold to leave this rope with you, sir, for a remembrance. Farewell mute.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The horn againcome, ha' me to my chamber: but first shut the door. O, shut the door, shut the door: is he come again?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: 'Tis I, sir, your barber.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O Cutberd, Cutberd, Cutberd! here has been a cutthroat with me: help me in to my bed, and give me physic with thy counsel.
Nay, and she will, let her refuse, at her own charges: 'tis nothing to me, gentlemen. But she will not be invited to the like feasts, or guests, every day.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: They dissuade her, privately.o, by no means, she may not refuse — to stay at home, if you love your reputation: 'slight, you are invited thither of purpose to be seen, and laughed at by the lady of the college, and her shadows. This trumpeter hath proclaimed you.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You shall not go; let him be laughed at in your stead, for not bringing you: and put him to his extemporal faculty of fooling, and talking loud to satisfy the company.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
He will suspect us, talk aloud. Pray, mistress Epicoene,
let's see your verses; we have sir John Daw's leave: do not conceal your servant's merit, and your own glories.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: They'll prove my servant's glories, if you have his leave so soon.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: His vain glories, lady!

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Show 'em, show 'em, mistress, I dare own 'em.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Judge you, what glories?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Nay, I'll read 'em myself, too: an author must recite his own work. It is a Madrigal of modesty.

lg.l: Modest, and fair, for fair and good are near
Neighbours, howe'er . —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ay, is't not?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.l: No noble virtue ever was alone,

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That again, I pray sir John.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: It has some thing in't like rare wit, and sense.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.l: No noble virtue ever was alone,
Then, when I praise sweet modesty, I praise
And having praised both beauty and modesty,

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How it chimes, and cries tinke i' the close, divinely!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis Seneca.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, I think 'tis Plutarch.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: The dor on Plutarch, and Seneca, I hate it: they are mine own imaginations, by that light. I wonder those fellows have such credit with gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: They are very grave authors.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p:
Grave asses! mere essayists! A few loose sentences, and that's all. A man would talk so, his whole age, I
do utter as good things every hour, if they were collected, and observed, as either of 'em.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Indeed! Sir John?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He must needs, living among the wits, and braveries too.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Ay, and being precedent of 'em, as he is.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: There's Aristotle, a mere common place-fellow; Plato, a discourser; Thucydides, and Livy, tedious and dry; Tacitus, an entire knot: sometimes worth the untying, very seldom.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What do you think of the poets, sir John?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not worthy to be named for authors. Homer, an old tedious prolix ass, talks of curriers, and chines of beef. Virgil, of dunging of land, and bees. Horace, of I know not what.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: And so Pindarus, Lycophron, Anacreon, Catullus, Seneca the tragedian, Lucan, Propertius, Tibullus, martial, Iwenal, Ausonius, Statius, Politian, Valerius Flaccus, and the rest —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a sackful of their names he has got!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: And how he pours 'em out! Politian, with Valerius Flaccus!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Was not the character right, of him?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: As could be made, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: And Persius, a crabbed coxcomb, not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why? whom do you account for authors, sir John daw?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Syntagma juris civilis, corpus juris civilis, corpus juris canonici, the King of Spain's bible.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Is the King of Spain's bible an author?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, and syntagma.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What was that syntagma, sir?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: A civil lawyer, a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Sure, Corpus was a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ay, both the corpusses, I knew 'em: they were very corpulent authors.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: And, then there's Vatablus, Pomponatius, Symancha, the other are not to be received, within the thought of a scholar.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Fore God, you have a simple learned servant, lady, in titles.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I wonder that he is not called to the helm, and made a councillor!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: He is one extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, but in ordinary! to say truth, the state wants such.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why, that will follow.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I muse, a mistress can be so silent to the dotes of such a servant.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: 'Tis her virtue, sir. I have written somewhat of her silence too.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: In verse, sir John?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why? how can you justify your own being of a poet, that so slight all the old poets?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Why? every man, that writes in verse, is not a poet; you have of the wits, that write verses, and yet are no poets: they are poets that live by it, the poor fellows that live by it.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why? would not you live by your verses, sir John?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, 'twere pity he should. A knight live by his verses? he did not make 'em to that end, I hope.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: And yet the noble Sidney lives by his, and the noble family not ashamed.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ay, he professed himself; but sir John Daw has more caution: he'll not hinder his own rising i' the state so much! do you think he will? Your verses, good sir John, and no poems.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.l: Silence in woman, is like speech in man,

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Not I, believe it: your reason, sir.

sp.speaker: Daup.

lg.l: Nor is't a tale,
That female vice should be a virtue male,
Or masculine vice, a female virtue be:
You shall it see
Proved with increase,
I know to speak, and she to hold her peace.

sp.p: Do you conceive me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: No faith, how mean you with increase, sir John?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Why, with increase is, when I court her for the common cause of mankind; and she says nothing, but consentire videtur: and in time is gravida.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Then, this is a ballad of procreation?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A Madrigal of procreation, you mistake.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Pray give me my verses again, servant.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: If you you'll ask 'em aloud, you shall.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: See, here's true-wit again!

div.head: Act ii. scene iiii.
div.stage: Clerimont, true-wit, Dauphine, Cutherd, Daw, Epicoene.

sp.p: Where hast thou been, in the name of madness! thus accoutred with thy horn?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Where the sound of it might have pierced your senses, with gladness, had you been in ear-reach of it. Dauphine, fall down and worship me: I have forbid the banes, lad. I have been with thy virtuous uncle, and have broke the match.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You ha' not, I hope.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Yes faith; and thou shouldst hope otherwise, I should repent me: this horn got me entrance, kiss it. I had no other way to get in, but by feigning to be a post; but when I got in once, I proved none, but rather the contrary, turned him into a post, or a stone, or what is stiffer, with
thundering into him the incommodities of a wife, and the miseries of marriage. If ever Gorgon were seen in the shape of a woman, he hath seen her in my description. I have put him off of that sent, for ever. Why do you not applaud, and adore me, sirs? why stand you mute? Are you stupid? you are not worthy of the benefit.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Did not I tell you? mischief! —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I would you had placed this benefit somewhere else.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Slight you have done the most inconsiderate, rash, weak thing, that ever man did to his friend.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Friend! if the most malicious enemy I have, had studied to inflict an injury upon me, it could not be a greater.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Wherein? for god's sake! Gent, come to yourselves again.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: But I presaged thus much afore, to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Would my lips had been soldered, when I spoke on't. 'slight, what moved you to be thus impertinent?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: My masters, do not put on this strange face to pay my courtesy: off with this visor. Have good turns done you and thank 'em this way?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Fore heaven, you have undone me. That, which I have plotted for, and been maturing now these four months, you have blasted in a minute: now I am lost, I may speak. This gentlewoman was lodged here by me of purpose, and, to be put upon my uncle, hath professed this obstinate silence for my sake, being my entire friend; and one, that for the requital of such a fortune, as to marry him, would have made me very ample conditions: where now, all my hopes are utterly miscarried by this unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thus 'tis, when a man will be ignorantly officious; do services, and not know his why: I wonder what courteous itch possessed you! you never did absurder part i' your life, nor a greater trespass to friendship, to humanity.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Faith, you may forgive it, best: 'twas your cause principally.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I know it, would it had not.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: How now, Cutberd? what news?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The best, the happiest that ever was, sir. There has been a mad gentleman with your uncle, this morning, (I think this be the gentleman) that has almost talked him out of his wits, with threatening him from marriage —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: On, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And your uncle, sir, he thinks 'twas done by your procurement; therefore he will see the party, you wot of, presently: and if he like her, he says, and that she be so inclining to dumb, as I have told him, he swears, he will marry her, today, instantly, and not defer it a minute longer.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Excellent! beyond our expectation!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Beyond your expectation? by this light, I knew, it would be thus.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Nay, sweet true-wit, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, I was ignorantly officious, impertinent: this was the absurd, weak part.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Wilt thou ascribe that to merit, now, was mere fortune?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Fortune? mere providence. Fortune had not a finger in't. I saw it must necessarily in nature fall out so: my genius is never false to me in these things. Show me, how it could be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, contend not, 'tis well now.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Alas, I let him go on with inconsiderate, and rash, and what he pleased.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Away thou strange justifier of thyself, to be wiser than thou wert, by the event.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Event! By this light, thou shalt never persuade me, but I foresaw it, as well as the stars themselves.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, 'tis well now do you two entertain sir John daw, with discourse, while I send her away with instructions.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I'll be acquainted with her, first, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Master true-wit, lady, a friend of ours.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I am sorry, I have not known you sooner, lady, to celebrate this rare virtue of your silence.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Faith, an' you had come sooner, you should ha' seen, and heard her well celebrated in sir John Daw's madrigals.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Jack daw, God save you, when saw you la-foole?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not since last night, master true-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That's miracle! I thought you two had been inseparable.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: He's gone to invite his guests.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: God's so! 'tis true! what a false memory have I towards that man! I am one: I met him e'en now, upon that he calls his delicate fine black horse, rid into a foam, with posting from place to place, and person to person, to give hem the cue —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Lest they should forget?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes: there was never poor captain took more pains at a muster to show men, than he, at this meal, to show friends.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: It is his quarter-feast, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What! do you say so, sir John?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, Jack daw will not be out, at the best friends he has, to the talon of his wit: where's his mistress, to hear and applaud him? is she gone!

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Is mistress Epicoene gone?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Gone afore, with sir Dauphine, I warrant to the place.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Gone afore! that were a manifest injury; a disgrace and a half: to refuse him at such a festival time, as this, being a bravery, and a wit too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Tut, he'll swallow it like cream: he's better read in jure civili, then to esteem any thing a disgrace is offered him from a mistress.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p:
Nay, let her e'en go; she shall sit alone, and be
dumb in her chamber, a week together, for John daw, I warrant her: does she refuse me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, sir, do not take it so to heart: she does not refuse you, but a little neglect you. Good faith, true-wit, you were too blame to put it into his head, that she does refuse him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: She does refuse him, sir, palpably: however you mince it. An' I were as he, I would swear to speak never a word to her, today, for't.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: By this light, no more I will not.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nor to anybody else, sir.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Nay, I will not say so, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: It had been an excellent happy condition for the company, if you could have drawn him to it.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I'll be very melancholic, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: As a dog, if I were as you, sir John.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Or a snail, or a hog-louse: I would roll myself up for this day, introth, they should not unwind me.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: By this picktooth, so I will.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis well done: he begins already to be angry with his teeth.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Will you go, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, you must walk alone, if you be right melancholic, sir John.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes sir, we'll dog you, we'll follow you afar off.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Was there ever such a two yards of knighthood, measured out by time, to be sold to laughter?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A mere talking mole! no mushroom was ever so fresh. A fellow so utterly nothing, as he knows not what he would be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Let's follow him: but first, let's go to Dauphine, he's hovering about the house, to hear what news.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Content.

Welcome Cutberd; draw near with your fair charge: and, in her ear, softly entreat her to unmask (—) so. Is the door shut? (—) enough. Now, Cutberd, with the same discipline I use to my family, I will question you. As I conceive, Cutberd, this gentlewoman is she, you have provided, and brought, in hope she will fit me in the place and person of a wise? Answer me not, but with your leg, unless it be otherwise: (—) very well done, Cutberd. I conceive, besides, Cutberd, you have been pre-acquainted with her birth, education, and qualities, or else you would not prefer her to my acceptance, in the weighty consequence of marriage. (—) this I conceive, Cutberd. Answer me not but with your leg, unless it be otherwise. (—) very well done Cutberd. Give aside now a little,He goes about her, and views her.and leave me to examine her condition, and aptitude to my affection. She is exceeding fair, and of a special good favour; a sweet composition, or harmony of limbs: her temper of beauty has the true height of my blood. The knave hath exceedingly well fitted me without: I will now try her within. Come near, fair gentlewoman: let not my behaviour seem rude, though unto you, being rare, it may happily appear strange. (—) nay, lady,She curtsies.you may speak, though Cutberd, and my man, might not: for, of all sounds, only, the sweet voice of a fair lady has the just length of mine ear. I beseech you, say lady, out of the first fire of meeting eyes, (They say) love is stricken; do you feel any such motion, suddenly shot into you, from any part you see in me? ha, lady? (—) alas, lady, these answers by silent curtsies, from you, are too courtless, and simple. Curt'sie.I have ever had my breeding in court: and she that shall be
my wife, must be accomplished with courtly, and audacious ornaments. Can you speak, lady?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Judge you, forsooth. She speaks softly.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What say you, lady? speak out, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Judge you, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: On my judgement, a divine softness! but can you naturally, lady, as I enjoin these by doctrine and industry, refer yourself to the search of my judgement, and (Not taking pleasure in your tongue, which is a woman's chiefest pleasure) think it plausible, to answer me by silent gestures, so long as my speeches jump right, with what you conceive? Curt'sie.(—) excellent! Divine! if it were possible, she should hold out thus! Peace, Cutherd, thou art made for ever, as thou hast made me, if this felicity have lasting: but I will try her further. Dear lady, I am courtly, I tell you, and I must have mine ears banqueted with pleasant, and witty conferences, pretty girds, scoffs, and dalliance in her, that I mean to choose for my bedfere. The ladies in court, think it a most desperate impair to their quickness of wit, and good carriage, if they cannot give occasion for a man to court 'em; and, when an amorous discourse is set on foot, minister as good matter to continue it, as himself: and do you alone so much differ from all them, that, what they (With so much circumstance) affect, and toil for, to seem learned, to seem judicious, to seem sharp, and conceited, you can bury in yourself, with silence? and rather trust your graces to the fair conscience of virtue, then to the worlds, or your own proclamation?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I should be sorry else.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What say you, lady? good lady, speak out.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I should be sorry, else

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
That sorrow doth fill me with gladness! O Morose! thou art happy above mankind! pray that thou mayest contain thyself. I will only put her to it once more, and it shall be with the utmost touch, and test of their sex. But
hear me, fair lady, I do also love to see her, whom I shall choose for my heifer, to be the first and principal in all fashions; precede all the dames at court, by a fortight; have her counsel of tailors, linneners, lace-women, embroiderers, and sit with 'em sometimes twice a day, upon French intelligences; and then come forth, varied like nature, or oftener than she, and better, by the help of art, her emulous servant. This do I affect. And how will you be able, lady, with this frugality of speech, to give the manifold (But necessary) instructions, for that bodies, these sleeves, those skirts, this cut, that stitch, this embroidery, that lace, this wire, those knots, that ruff, those roses, this girdle, that fan, the tother scarf, these gloves? ha! what say you, lady.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'll leave it to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How, lady? pray you, rise a note.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I leave it to wisdom, and you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Admirable creature! I will trouble you no more: I will not sin against so sweet a simplicity. Let me now be bold to print, on those divine lips, the seal of being mine. Cutberd, I give thee the lease of thy house free: thank me not, but with thy leg (—) I know what thou wouldst say, she's poor, and her friends deceased; she has brought a wealthy dowry in her silence, Cutberd: and in respect of her poverty, Cutberd, I shall have her more loving, and obedient, Cutberd. Go thy ways, and get me a minister presently, with a soft, low voice to marry us, and pray him he will not be impertinent, but brief as he can; away: softly, Cutberd. Sirrah, conduct your mistress into the dining room, your now-mistris. O my felicity! how I shall be revenged on mine insolent kinsman, and his plots to fright me from marrying! This night I will get an heir, and thrust him out of my blood like a stranger; he would be knighted, forsooth, and thought by that means to reign over me, his title must do it: no kinsman, I will now make you
bring me the tenth lords, and the sixteenth lady's letter, kinsman; and it shall do you no good, kinsman. Your knighthood itself shall come on it's knees, and it shall be rejected; it shall be sued for it's fees to execution, and not be redeemed; it shall cheat at the twelvepenny ordinary, it knighthood, for it's diet all the termtime, and tell tales for it in the vacation, to the hostess: or it knighthood shall do worse; take sanctuary in Coleharbour, and fast. It shall fright all it friends, with borrowing letters, and when one of the fourscore hath brought it knighthood ten shillings, it knighthood shall go to the cranes, or the bear at the bridge-foot, and be drunk in fear: it shall not have money to discharge one tavern reckoning, to invite the old creditors, to forbear it knighthood; or the new, that should be, to trust it knighthood. It shall be the tenth name in the bond, to take up the commodity of pipkins and stone jugs; and the part thereof shall not furnish it knighthood forth, for the attempting of a baker's widow, a brown baker's widow. It shall give it knighthood's name, for a stallion, to all gamesome citizens' wives, and be refused; when the master of a dancing school, or (How do you call him) the worst reveller in the town is taken: it shall want clothes, and by reason of that, wit, to fool to lawyers. It shall not have hope to repair itself by Constantinople, Ireland, or Virginia; but the best, and last fortune to it knighthood shall be, to make Dol Tearsheet, or Kate-common, a lady: and so, it knighthood may eat.
Are you sure he is not gone by?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: No, I stayed in the shop ever since.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But, he may take the other end of the lane.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: No, I told him I would be here at this end: I appointed him hither.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What a barbarian it is to stay then!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And his charge left behind him, which is a very good sign, Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: How now Cutberd, succeeds it, or no?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Past imagination, sir, omnia secunda; you could not have prayed, to have had it so well: saltat senex, as it is i'the proverb, he does triumph in his felicity; admires the party! he has given me the lease of my house too! and, I am now going for a silent minister to marry 'em, and away.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Slight, get one of the silenced ministers, a zealous brother would torment him purely.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Cum privilegio, sir.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: O, by no means, let's do nothing to hinder it now when 'tis done and finished, I am for you: for any device of vexation.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And that shall be within this half hour, upon my dexterity, gentlemen. Contrive what you can, in the mean time, bonis avibus.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How the slave doth Latin it!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: It would be made a jest to posterity, sirs, this day's mirth, if ye will.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Be shrew his heart that will not, I pronounce.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: And, for my part. What is't?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: To translate all La-fooles company, and his feast hither, today, to celebrate this bride-ale.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I marry, but how will't be done?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I'll undertake the directing of all the ladie-guests thither, and then the meat must follow.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: For god's sake, let's effect it: it will be an excellent comedy of affliction, so many several noises.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: But are they not at the other place already, think you?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I'll warrant you for the college-honours: one of their faces has not the priming colour laid on yet, nor the other her smock sleeked.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, but they'll rise earlier than ordinary, to a feast.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Best go see, and assure ourselves.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Who knows the house?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I'll lead you, were you never there yet?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Where ha' you lived then? not know tom otter!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No: for God's sake, what is he?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: An excellent animal, equal with your daw, or la-foole, if not transcendent; and does Latin it as much as your barber: he is his wife's subject, he calls her Princess, and at such times as these, follows her up and down the house like a page, with his hat off, partly for heat, partly for reverence. At this instant, he is marshalling of his bull, bear, and horse.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What be those, in the name of Sphinx?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why sir? he has been a great man at the bear-garden in his time: and from that subtle sport, has ta'en the witty denomination of his chief carousing cups. One he calls his bull, another his bear, another his horse. And then he has his lesser glasses, that he calls his deer, and his ape; and several degrees of 'em too: and never is well, nor thinks any entertainment perfect, till these be brought out, and set of the cupboard.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: For god's love! we should miss this, if we should not go.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, he has a thousand things as good, that will speak him all day. He will rail on his wife, with certain common places, behind her back; and to her face —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: No more of him. Let's go see him, I petition you,

div.head: Scene i.
div.stage: Otter, mrs. Otter, Tru-wit, Clerimont, Dauphine.

sp.p: Nay, good Princess, hear me pauca verba.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: By that light, I'll of you chained up, with your bulldogs, and bear-dogs, if you be not civil the sooner. I'll send you to kennel, i'faith. You were best bait me with your bull, bear, and horse? Never a time, that the courtiers, or collegiates come to the house, but you make it a Shrove-tuesday! I would have you get your whitsuntide-velvet-cap, and your staff i'your hand, to entertain 'em: yes in troth, do.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Not so Princess, neither, but under correction, sweet Princess, gi'me leave — these things I am known to the courtiers by. It is reported to them for my humour, and they receive it so, and do expect it. Tom otters bull, bear, and horse is known all over England, in rerum natura.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Fore me, I will nature 'em over to paris-garden, and nature you thither too, if you pronounce them again. Is a bear a fit beast, or a bull, to mix in society with great ladies? think i'your discretion, in any good polity.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: The horse then, good Princess.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Well, I am contented for the horse: they love to be well horsed, I know. I love it myself.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And it is a delicate fine horse. Poetarum Pegasus. Under correction, Princess, Jupiter did turn himself into a — Taurus, or bull, under correction, good Princess.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p:
By my integrity, I'll send you over to the Bankside, I'll commit you to the master of the garden, if I hear but a syllable more. Must my house, or my roof, be polluted with the scent of bears, and bulls, when it is perfumed
for great ladies? Is this according to the instrument, when I married you? That I would be Princess, and reign in mine own house: and you would be my subject, and obey me? What did you bring me, should make you thus peremptory? Do I allow you your half-crown a day, to spend, where you will, among your gamesters, to vex and torment me, at such times as these? Who gives you your maintenance, I pray you? who allows you your horse-meat, and mans-meat? your three suits of apparel a year? your four pair of stockings, one silk, three worsted? your clean linen, your bands, and cuffs when I can get you to wear 'em? 'tis mar'le you ha'hem on now. Who graces you with courtiers, or great personages, to speak to you out of their coaches, and come home to your house? Were you ever so much as looked upon by a lord, or a lady, before I married you: but on the easter, or whitson-holy-dayes? and then out at the banqueting-house window, when Ned whiting, or George stone, were at the stake?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (For God's sake, let's go stave her off him.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Answer me to that. And did not I take you up from thence, in an old greasy buff-doublet, with points; and green velvet sleeves, out at the elbows? you forget this.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (She'll worry him, if we help not in time.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O, here are some of the gallants! Go to, behave yourself distinctly, and with good morality; or, I protest, I'll take away your exhibition.

div.head: Act iii. Scene ii.
div.stage: Tru-wit, Mrs. Otter, Cap. Otter, Clerimont, Dauphine, Cutberd.

sp.p: By your leave, fair mistress Otter, I'll be bold to enter these gentlemen in your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: It shall not be obnoxious, or difficile, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How does my noble captain? Is the bull, bear, and horse, in rerum natura still?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Sir. Sic visum superis.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ott.
sp.p: I would you would but intimate 'em, do. Go your ways in, and get toasts, and butter, made for the woodcocks. That's a fit province for you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas, what a tyranny, is this poor fellow married too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, but the sport will be anon, when we get him lose.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Dares be ever speak?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No Anabaptist ever railed with the like licence: but mark her language in the meantime, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are very aptly come. My cousin, sir amorous, will be here briefly.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: In good time, lady. Was not sir John daw here, to ask for him, and the company?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: I cannot assure you, Mr. tru-wit. Here was a very melancholy knight in a ruff, that demanded my subject for somebody , a gentleman, I think.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ay, that was he, lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: But he departed straight, I can resolve you.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What an excellent choice phrase, this lady expresses in?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, sir! she is the only authentical courtier, that is not naturally bred one, in the city.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: You have taken that report upon trust, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, I assure you, the court governs it so, lady, in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: I am the servant of the court, and courtiers, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: They are rather your idolaters.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ot.
sp.p: Not so, sir.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: How now, Cutberd? Any cross?

div.p: And indeed, so ashamed of her injury to you, that she desires you to forgive her, and but grace her wedding with your presence today — she is to be married to a very good fortune, she says, his uncle, old Morose: and she willed me in private to tell you, that she shall be able to do you more favours, and with more security now, then before.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Did she say so, i'faith?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, what do you think of me, sir John! ask sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Nay, I believe you. Good sir Dauphine, did she desire me to forgive her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I assure you, sir John, she did.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Nay then, I do with all my heart, and I'll be jovial.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, for look you sir, this was the injury to you. La-foole intended this feast to honour her bridal day, and made you the property to invite the college ladies, and promise to bring her: and then at the time, she should have appeared (As his friend) to have given you the dor. Whereas now, sir Dauphine has brought her to a feeling of it, with this kind of satisfaction, that you shall bring all the ladies to the place where she is, and be very jovial; and there she will have a dinner, which shall be in your name: and so disappoint la-foole, to make you good again, and (As it were) a saver i'the man.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As I am a knight, I honour her, and forgive her heartily.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: About it then presently, tru-wit is gone before to confront the coaches, and to acquaint you with so much, if he meet you. Join with him, and 'tis well. See, here comes your antagonist, but take you no notice, but be very jovial.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Are the ladies come, sir John daw, and your mistress? Sir Dauphine! you are exceeding welcome, and honest master Clerimont. Where's my cousin? did you see no collegiates, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Collegiates! Do you not hear, sir amorous, how you are abused?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: How sir!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Will you speak so kindly to sir John daw, that has done you such an affront?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Wherein gentlemen? let me be a suitor to you to know, I beseech you!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why sir, his mistress is married today, to sir Dauphine's uncle, your cousin's neighbour, and he has diverted all the ladies, and all your company thither, to frustrate your provision, and stick a disgrace upon you. He was here, now, to have enticed us away from you too: but we told him his own, I think.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Has sir John Daw wronged me so inhumanely?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: He has done it, sir amorous, most maliciously, and treacherously: but if you'll be ruled by us, you shall quit him i'faith.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Good gentlemen! I'll make one, believe it. How I pray?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Marry sir, get me your pheasants, your godwits, and your best meat, and dish it in silver dishes of your cousins presently, and say nothing, but clap me a clean towel about you, like a sewer; and bareheaded, march afore it with a good confidence ('tis but over the way, hard by) and we'll second you, where you shall set of the board, and bid 'em welcome to't, which shall show 'tis yours, and disgrace his preparation utterly: and, for your cousin, whereas she should be troubled here at home with care of making and giving welcome, she shall transfer all that labour thither, and be a principal guest herself, sit ranked with the colledge-honors, and be honoured, and have her health drunk as often, as bare, and as loud as the best of 'em.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I'll go tell her presently. It shall be done, that's resolved.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I thought he would not hear it out, but 'twould take him.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Well, there be guests, and meat now; how shall we do for music?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: The smell of the venison, going through the street, will invite one noise of fiddlers, or other.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I would it would call the trumpeters thither.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Faith, there is hope, they have intelligence of all feasts. There's good correspondence betwixt them, and the london-cookes. 'tis twenty to one but we have 'em.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: 'Twill be a most solemn day for my uncle, and an excellent fit of mirth for us.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ay, if we can hold up the emulation betwixt fool and daw, and never bring them to expostulate.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Tut, flatter 'em both (As tru-wit says) and you may take their understandings in a pursenet. They'll believe themselves to be just such men as we make 'em, neither more nor less. They have nothing, not the use of their senses, but by tradition.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: See! sir amorous has his towel on already. He enters like a sewerhave you persuaded your cousin?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis very feasible: she'll do any thing, she says, rather than the La-fooles shall be disgraced.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: She is a noble kinswoman. It will be such a pestle device, sir amorous! It will pound all your enemies' practises to powder, and blow him up with his own mine, his own train.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Nay, we'll give fire, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But you must carry it privately, without any noise, and take no notice by any means —

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Princess says, you shall have all her silver dishes, festinate: and she's gone to alter her tire a little, and go with you —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And yourself too, captain Otter.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: By any means, sir.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Yes sir, I do mean it: but I would entreat my cousin sir amorous, and you gentlemen, to be suitors to my Princess, that I may carry my bull, and my bear, as well as my horse.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That you shall do, captain Otter.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: My cousin will never consent, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: She must consent, sir amorous, to reason.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Why, she says they are no decorum among ladies.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: But they are decora, and that's better, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ay, she must hear argument. Did not Pasiphae, who was a Queen, love a bull? and was not Calisto, the mother of Arcas, turned into a bear, and made a star, mistress Ursula, i'the heavens?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: O God! that I could ha' said as much! I will have these storeys painted i' the bear-garden, ex ouidij metamorphosi.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Where is your Princess, captain? pray be our leader.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: That I shall, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Make haste, good sir amorous.

Sir, there's an angel for yourself, and a brace of angels for your cold. Muse not at this manage of my bounty, it is fit, we should thank fortune, double to nature, for any benefit she confers upon us; besides, it is your imperfection, but my solace. The parson speaks, as having a cold.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I thank your worship, so is it mine, now.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What says he, Cutberd?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: He says, Praesto, sir, whensoever your worship needs him, he can be ready with the like. He got this cold with sitting up late, and singing catches with clothworkers.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No more. I thank him.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: God keep your worship, and give you much joy with your fair spouse. He coughs.(Umh, umb.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, o, stay Cutberd! let him give me five shillings of my money back. As it is bounty to reward benefits, so is it equity to mulct injuries. I will have it. What says he?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: He cannot change it, sir

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It must be changed.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Cough again.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What says he?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: He will cough out the rest, sir.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: (Umh,Again.umh, umh.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Away, away with him, stop his mouth, away, I forgive it. —

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Fie, master Morose, that you will use this violence to a man of the church.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: It does not become your gravity, or breeding, (As you pretend in court) to have offered this outrage on a waterman, or any more boisterous creature, much less on a man of his civil coat.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You can speak then!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Speak out I mean.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I sir. Why, did you think you had married a statue? or a motion, only? one of the French puppets, with the eyes turned with a wire? or some innocent out of the hospital that would stand with her hands thus, and a plaice mouth, and look upon you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O immodesty! A manifest woman! what Cutberd?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nay, never quarrel with Cutberd, sir, it is too late now. I confess, it doth bate somewhat of the modesty I had, when I writ simply maid: but I hope, I shall make it a stock still competent, to the estate, and dignity of your wife.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: She can talk!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What, sirrah. None of my knaves there? where is this impostor, Cutberd?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Speak to him, fellow, speak to him, I'll have none of this coacted, unnatural dumbness in my house, in a family where I govern.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: She is my regent already! I have married a Penthesilea, a Semiramis, sold my liberty to a distaff!
Where's master Morose?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is he come again! Lord have mercy upon me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I wish you all joy, mistress Epicoene, with your grave and honourable match.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I return you the thanks, master tru-wit, so friendly a wish deserves.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: She has acquaintance, too!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: God save you sir, and give you all contentment in your fair choice, here. Before I was the bird of night to you, the owl but now I am the messenger of peace, a dove, and bring you the glad wishes of many friends, to the celebration of this good hour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What hour, sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your marriage hour sir. I commend your resolution, that (Notwithstanding all the dangers I laid afore you, in the voice of a night-crow) would yet go on, and be yourself. It shows you are a man constant to your, own ends, and upright to your purposes, that would not be put off with left-handed cries.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How should you arrive at the knowledge of so much!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Why, did you ever hope, sir committing the secrecy of it to a barber, that less than the whole town should know it? you might as well ha' told it to the conduit, or the bakehouse, or the infantry that follow the court, and with more security. Could your gravity forget so old and noted a remnant, as, lippis et tonsoribus notum, well sir, forgive it yourself now, the fault, and be communicable
with your friends. Here will be three or four fashionable ladies, from the college to visit you presently, and their train of minions, and followers.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Bar my doors! bar my doors! where are all my eaters? my mouths now? baire up my doors, you varlets.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: He is a varlet, that stirs to such an office. Let 'em stand open. I would see him that dares move his eyes towards it. Shall I have a barricado made against my friends, to be barred of any pleasure they can bring in to me with honourable visitation.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O Amazonian impudence!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay faith, in this, sir, she speaks but reason: and methinks is more continent than you. Would you go to bed so presently, sir, afore noon? A man of your head, and hair, should owe more to that reverend ceremony, and not mount the marriage-bed, like a town-bull, or a mountain-goat; but stay the due season; and ascend it then with religion, and fear. Those delights are to be steeped in the humour, and silence of the night; and give the day to other open pleasures, and jollities of feast, of music, of revels, of discourse: we'll have all, sir, that may make your Hymen high, and happy.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, my torment, my torment!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, if you endure the first half hour, sir, so tediously, and with this irksomeness; what comfort, or hope, can this fair gentlewoman make to herself hereafter, in the consideration of so many years as are to come —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Of my affliction. Good sir, depart, and let her do it alone.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I have done, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: That cursed barber!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (Yes faith, a cursed wretch indeed, sir.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have married his cittern, that's common to all men. Some plague above the plague —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (All Egypt's ten plagues)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Revenge me on him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, sir. If you laid on a curse or two, more, I'll assure you he'll bear 'em. As, that he may get the pox with seeking to cure it, sir? Or, that while he is curling another man's hair, his own may drop off? Or, for burning some male-baudes lock, he may have his brain beat out with the curling-iron?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, let the wretch live wretched. May he get the itch, and his shop so lousy, as no man dare come at him, nor he come at no man.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (Ay, and if he would swallow all his balls for pills, let not them purge him)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let his warming-pan be ever cold.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (A perpetual frost underneath it, sir)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let him never hope to see fire again.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (But in hell, sir)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: His chairs be always empty, his scissors rust, and his combs mould in their cases.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Very dreadful that! (And may he lose the invention, sir, of carving lanterns in paper)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let there be no bawd carted that year, to employ a basin of his: but let him be glad to eat his sponge, for bread.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And drink lotium to it, and much good do him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Or, for want of bread —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Eat earwax, sir. I'll help you. Or draw his own teeth, and add them to the lutestring.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, beat the old ones to powder, and make bread of them.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (Yes, make meal of the millstones.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: May all the botches, and burns, that he has cured on others, break out upon him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And he now forget the cure of 'em in himself, sir: or, if he do remember it, let him ha' scraped all his linen into lint for't, and have not a rag left him, to set up with.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That falls out often, madam, that he that thinks himself the master-wit, is the master-fool. I assure your ladyship, ye cannot laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: No, we'll have her to the college: and she have wit, she shall be one of us.! shall she not centaur? we'll make her a collegiate.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Yes faith, madam, and Mavis, and she will set up aside .

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Believe it madam, and mistress Mavis, she will sustain her part.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I'll tell you that, when I have talked with her, and tried her.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Use her very civilly, Mavis.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: So I will, madam.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Blessed minute, that they would whisper thus ever.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: In the the mean time, madam, would but your ladyship help to vex him a little: you know his disease, talk to him about the wedding ceremonies, or call for your gloves, or —

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Let me alone. Centaur, help me. Master bridegroom, where are you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, it was too miraculously good to last!

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: We see no ensigns of a wedding, here; no character of a bride-ale: where be our scarves, and our gloves? I pray you, give 'em us. Let's know your bride's colours, and yours, at least.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Alas, madam, he has provided none.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Had I known your ladyship's painter, I would.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p:
He has given it you, centaur, i'faith. But do you hear master Morose, a jest will not absolve you in this manner. You that have sucked the milk of the court, and from thence have been brought up to the very strong meats, and wine, of it; been a courtier from the biggin, to the nightcap: (As we may say) and you, to offend in such a high point of ceremony, as this and let your nuptials
want all marks of solemnity! How much plate have you lost today (If you had but regarded your profit) what gifts, what friends, through your mere rusticity?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Madam —

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, I must insinuate your errors to you. No gloves? no garters? no scarves? no epithalamium? no masque?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I'll make an epithalamium, I promised my mistress, I have begun it already: will your ladyship hear it?

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Ay, good Jack daw.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Will it please your ladyship command a chamber, and be private with hour friend? you shall have your choice of rooms, to retire to after: my whole house is yours. I know, it hath been your Ladyship's errand, into the city, at other times, however now you have been unhappily diverted upon me ▪ but I shall be loath to break any honourable custom of your ladyships. And therefore, good madam —

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Come, you are a rude bridegroom, to entertain ladies of honour in this fashion.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p: He is a rude groom, indeed.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By that light, you deserve to grafted, and have your horn's reach from one side of the island, to the other. Do not mistake me, sir, I but speak this, to give the ladies some heart again, not for any malice to you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is this your Brau●, ladies?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: As God help me, if you utter such another word, I'll take mistress Bride in and begin to you, in a very sad cup, do you see? Go too, know your friends, and such, as love you.

div.head: Act iii. Scene vii.
div.stage: Clerimont, Morose, Tru-wit, Dauphine, La-foole, otter, Mrs. Otter, etc.

sp.p: By your leave, ladies. Do you want any music? I have brought you variety of noises. Play, sirs, all of you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Music of all sorts.o, a plot, a plot, a plot, a plot upon me! This day, I shall be their anvil to work on, they will grate me asunder. 'tis worse than the noise of a saw.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, they are hair, rosin, and guts. I can give you the receipt.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Peace, boys.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Play, I say.

sp.speaker: Tru.
