sp.p: Peace, rascals. You see who's your friend now, sir? Take courage, put on a martyr's resolution. Mock down all their attemptings, with patience. 'tis but a day, and I would suffer heroically. Should an ass exceed me in fortitude? No. You betray your infirmity with your hanging dull ears, and make them insult: bear up bravely, and constantly. Look you here, sir, what honour is done you unexpected,La-foole passes over sewing the ●eate.by your nephew; a wedding dinner come, and a knight sewer before it, for the more reputation: and fine mistress Otter, your neighbour, in the rump, or tail of it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is that Gorgon, that Medusa come? Hide me, hide me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I warrant you, sir, she will not transform you. Look upon her with a good courage. Pray you entertain her, and conduct your guests in, no? Mistress Bride, will you entreat in the ladies? your bridegroom is so shamefaced, here —

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Will it please your ladyship, madam?

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: With the benefit of your company, mistress.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Servant, pray you perform your duties.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: And glad to be commanded, mistress.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: How like you her wit, Mavis.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Very prettily, absolutely well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: 'Tis my place.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: You shall pardon me, mistress Otter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Why, I am a collegiate.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: But not in ordinary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: But I am.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: We'll dispute that within.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Would this had lasted a little longer.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And that they had sent for the heralds. Captain Otter, what news?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I have brought my bull, bear, and horse, in private, and yonder are the trumpeters without, and the drum, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, o, ô.The drum, and trumpets sound,

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And we will have a rouse in each of 'em, anon, for bold Britons, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.
Was there ever poor bridegroom so tormented? or man indeed?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I have not read of the like, in the chronicles of the land.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sure, he cannot but go to a place of rest, after all this purgatory.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He may presume it, I think.

sp.speaker: Tru
sp.p:
The spitting, the coughing, the laughter, the neesing, the farting, dancing, noise of the music, and her masculine, and loud commanding, and urging the whole
family, makes him think he has married a fury.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And she carries it up bravely.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, she takes any occasion to speak: that's the height on't.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And how soberly Dauphine labours to satisfy him, that it was none of his plot!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And has almost brought him to the faith, i' the article. Here he comes. Where is he now? what's become of him, Dauphine?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: O, hold me up a little, I shall go away i' the jest else. He has got on his whole nest of nightcaps, and locked himself up, i' the top of the house, as high as ever he can climb from the noise. I peeped in at a cranny, and saw him sitting over a cross-beam of the roof, like him of the sadler's horse in Fleetstreet, upright: and he will sleep there.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But where are your collegiates?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Withdrawn with the bride in private.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, they are instructing her i' the college-grammar. If she have grace with them, she knows all their secrets instantly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: methinks , the lady haughty looks well today, for all my dispraise of her i' the morning. I think, I shall come about to thee again, tru-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Believe it, I told you right. Women ought to repair the losses, time and years have made i' their features, with dressings. And an intelligent woman, if she know by herself the least defect, will be most curious, to hide it: and it becomes her. If she be short, let her sit much, lest when she stands, she be thought to sit. If she have an ill foot, let her wear her gown the longer, and her shoe the thinner. If a fat hand, and scald nails, let her carve the less, and act in gloves. If a sour breath, let her never discourse fasting: and always talk at her distance. If she have black and rugged teeth, let her offer the less at laughter, especially if she laugh wide, and open.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, you shall have some women, when they laugh, you would think they brayed, it is so rude, and —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, and others, that will stalk i'their gait like an ostrich, and take huge strides. I cannot endure such a sight. I love measure i' the feet, and number i' the voice: they are gentlenesses, that oft-times draw no less than the face.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: How cam'st thou to study these creatures so exactly? I would thou wouldst make me a proficient.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, but you must leave to live i' your chamber than a month together upon Amadis de Gaul, or don Quixote, as you are wont; and come abroad where the matter is frequent, to court, to tiltings, public shows, and feasts, to plays, and church sometimes: thither they come to show their new tires too, to see, and to be seen. In these places a man shall find whom to love, whom to play with, whom to touch once, whom to hold ever. The variety arrests his judgement. A wench to please a man comes not down dropping from the ceiling, as he lies on his back droning a tobacco pipe. He must go where she is.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes, and be never the near.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Out heretic. That diffidence makes thee worthy, it should be so.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He says true to you, Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A man should not doubt to over come any woman. Think he can vanquish 'em, and he shall, for though they deny, their desire is to be tempted. Penelope herself cannot hold out long. Ostend, you saw, was taken at last. You must persever, and hold to your purpose. They would solicit us, but that they are afraid. Howsoever, they wish in their hearts we should solicit them. Praise them, flatter. 'em, you shall never want eloquence, or trust: even the chastest delight to feel themselves that way rubbed. With praises you must mix kisses too. If they take them, they'll take more. Though they strive, they would be overcome.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, but a man must beware of force.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: It is to them an acceptable violence, and has oft-times the place of the greatest courtesy. She that might have been forced, and you let her go free without touching though she then seem to thank you, will ever hate you after: and glad i' the face, is assuredly sad at the heart.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But all women are not to be taken always.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
'Tis true. No more than all birds, or all fishes. If you appear learned to an ignorant wench, or jocund to a sad, or witty to a foolish, why she presently begins to mistrust herself. You must approach them i' their own height, their own line: for the contrary makes many that fear to commit themselves to noble and worthy fellows, run into the embraces of a rascal. If she love wit, give verses, though you borrow 'em of a friend, or buy 'em, to have good. If valour, talk of your sword, and be frequent in the mention of quarrels, though you be staunch in fighting. If activity be seen o'your Barbary often, or leaping over stools, for the credit of your back. If she love good clothes or dressing have your learned counsel about you every morning, your French tailor, barber, linener, etc. Let your powder, your glass, and your comb, be your dearest acquaintance. Take more care for the ornament of your head, than the safety: and wish the commonwealth rather troubled, than a hair about you. That will take her. Then if she be covetous and craving, do you promise any thing, and perform sparingly: so shall you keep her in appetite still. Seem as you would give, but be like a barren field that yields little, or unlucky dice, to foolish, and hoping gamesters. Let your gifts be flight, and dainty, ra her then precious. Let cunning be above cost. Give cherries at time of year, or apricots; and say they were sent you out of the country, though you bought 'em in Cheapside. Admire her tires; like her in all fashions; compare her in every habit to some deity; invent excellent dreams to flatter her, and riddles; or, if she be a great one, perform always the second
parts to her: like what she likes, praise whom she praises, and fail not to make the household and servants yours, yea the whole family, and salute 'em by their names: ('tis but light cost if you can purchase 'em so) and make her physician your pensioner, and her chief woman. Nor will it be out of your gain to make love to her too, so she follow, not usher, her lady's pleasure. All blabbing is taken away, when she comes to be a part of the crime.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: On what courtly lap hast thou late slept, to come forth so sudden and absolute a courtling?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Good faith, I should rather question you, that are so harkening after these mysteries. I begin to suspect your diligence, Dauphine. Speak, art thou in love in earnest?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes by my troth am I: 'twere ill dissembling before thee.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: With which of 'em, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: With all the collegiates.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Out on thee. We'll keep you at home, believe it, i' the stable, and you be such a stallion.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, I like him well. Men should love wisely, and all women: someone for the face, and let her please the eye; another for the skin, and let her please the touch; a third for the voice, and let her please the ear; and where the objects mix, let the senses so too. Thou wouldst think it strange, if I should make 'em all in love with thee a fore night!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I would say thou hadst the best philtre i' the world, and couldst do more than madam Medea, or doctor foreman.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: If I do not, let me play the mountebank for my meat while I live, and the bawd for my drink.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: So be it, I say.

div.head: Act iv. Scene ii.
div.stage: Otter, Clerimont, Daw, Dauphine, Morose, Tru-wit, La-foole, Mrs. Otter.

sp.p: O lord, gentlemen, how my knights and I have missed you here!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, captain, what service? what service?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: To see me bring up my bull, bear, and horse to fight.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes faith, the captain says we shall be his dogs to bait 'em.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: A good employment.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Come on, let's see a course then.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I am afraid my cousin will be offended if she come.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Be afraid of nothing. Gentlemen, I have placed the drum and the trumpets, and one to give 'em the sign when you are ready. Here's my bull for myself, and my bear for sir John daw, and my horse for sir amorous. Now set your foot to mine, and yours to his, and —

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Pray God my cousin come not.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Saint George, and saint Andrew, fear no cousins. Come, sound, sound. Et rauco strepuerunt cornuacantu.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well said, captain, i'faith: well fought at the bull.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well held at the bear.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Low, low, captain.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: On the horse has kicked off his dog already.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I cannot drink it, as I am a knight.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: God's so, off with his spurs, somebody.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: It goes again my conscience. My cousin will be angry with it.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I ha' done mine.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You fought high and fair, sir John.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: At the head.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Like an excellent bear-dog.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You take no notice of the business I hope.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not a word, sir, you see we are jovial.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Sir amorous, you must not equivocate. It must be pulled down, for all my cousin.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, if you take not your drink, they'll think you are discontented with some thing: you'll betray all, if you take the least notice.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Not I, I'll both drink, and talk then.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You must pull the horse on his knees, sir amorous: fear no cousins. Jacta est alea.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, now he's in his vain, and bold. The least hint given him of his wife now will make him rail desperately.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Speak to him of her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Do you, and I'll fetch her to the hearing of it.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Captain he-otter, your shee-otter is coming, your wife.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Wife! Buz. Titinilitium. There's no such thing in nature. I confess, gentlemen, I have a cook, a laundress, a house-drudge, that serves my necessary turns, and goes under that title: but he's an ass that will be so uxorious, to tie his affections to one circle. Come, the name dulls appetite. Here, replenish again: another bout. Wiues are nasty, sluttish animals.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, captain.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: As ever the earth bore, tribus verbis. Where's master tru-wit?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: He's slipped aside, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But you must drink, and be jovial,

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes, give it me.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: And me, too.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Let's be jovial.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: As jovial as you will.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p:
Agreed. Now you shall ha' the bear, cousin, and sir John Daw the horse, and I'll ha' the bull still. Sound
Tritons of the Thames. Nunc est bibendum, nunc pede libero —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Morose speaks from above: the trumpets sounding.villains, murderers, sons of the earth, and traitors, what do you there?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, now the trumpets have waked him, we shall have his company.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: A wife is a scurvy clogdogdo; an unlucky thing, a very foresaid bear-whelp, without any good fashion or breeding: mala bestia.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why did you marry one then, captain?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: His wife is brought out to bear him.a pox — I married with six thousand pound, I. I was in love with that. I ha' not kissed my fury these forty weeks.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: The more to blame you, captain.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, mistress Otter, hear him a little first.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: She has a breath worse than my grandmothers, profecto.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O treacherous liar. Kiss me sweet master tru-wit, and prove him a slandering knave.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I'll rather believe you, lady.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And she has a peruke, that's like a pound of hemp, made up in shoo-thrids.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O viper, mandrake!

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: A most vile face! and yet she spends me forty pound a year in Mercury, and hogs-bones. All her teeth were made i'the Blackfriars: both her eyebrows i'the strand, and her hair in Siver-street. Every part of the town owns a piece of her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: I cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: She takes herself asunder still when she goes to bed, into some twenty boxes; and about next day noon is put together again, like a great German clock: and so comes forth and rings a tedious alarm to the whole house, and then is quiet again for an hour, but for her quarters. Have you done me right, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: No, sir, I'll do you right with my quarters, with my quarters.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: She falls upon him and beats upon him,oh, hold, good Princess.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sound, sound.

sp.speaker: Cl●.
sp.p: A battle, a battle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: You notorious stinkardly bearward, does my breath smell?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Under correction, dear Princess: look to my bear, and my horse, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Do I want teeth, and eyebrows, thou bulldog?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sound, sound still.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: No, I protest, under correction —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ott.
sp.p: Ay, now you are under correction, you protest: but you did not protest before correction, sir. Thou Judas, to offer to betray thy Princess! I'll make thee an example —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Morose descends with a longswordI will have no such examples in my house, lady Otter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Ah —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mistress Mary Ambree, your examples are dangerous. Rogues, hellhounds, Stentours, out of my doors, you sons of noise and tumult, begotten on an ill May-day, or when the galley-foist is afloat to Westminster! A trumpeter could not be conceived but then!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What ails you, sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: They have rent my roof, walls, and all my windows asunder, with their brazen throats.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Best follow him, Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: So I will.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Where's Daw, and la-foole?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: They are both run away, sir. Good gentlemen, help to pacify my Princess, and speak to the great ladies for me. Now must I go lie with the bears this fortnight, and keep out of the way, till my peace be made, for this scandal she has taken. Did you not see my bullhead, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is't not on, captain?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No: but he may make a new one, by that, is on.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: O, here 'tis. And you come over, gentlemen, and ask for Tom Otter, we'll go down to Ratcliffe, and have a course i'faith: for all these disasters. There's bona spit left.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Away, captain, get off while you are well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am glad we are rid of him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You had never been, unless we had put his wife upon him. His humour is as tedious at last, as it was ridiculous at first.

div.head: Act iv. Scene iii.
div.stage: Haughty, mistress Otter, Mavis, Daw, La-foole, cenraure, Epicoene, Tru-wit, Clerimont.

sp.p: We wondered why you shrieked so, mistress Otter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O God, madam, he came down with a huge long naked weapon in both his hands, and looked so dreadfully! Sure, he's beside himself.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Why, what made you there, mistress Otter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Alas, mistress Mavis, I was chastising my subject, and thought nothing of him.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Faith, mistress, you must do so too. Learn to chastise. Mistress Otter corrects her husband so, he dares not speak, but under correction.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: And with his hat off to her: 'twould do you good to see.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: In sadness 'tis good, and mature counsel: practise it, Morose. I'll call you Morose still now, as I call centaur, and Mavis: we four will be all one.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And you'll come to the college, and live with us?

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Make him give milk, and honey.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Look how you manage him at first, you shall have him ever after.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p:
Let him allow you your coach, and four horses,
your woman, your chambermaid, your page your gentleman-usher, your French cook, and four grooms.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: And go with us, to bedlam, to the china houses, and to the exchange.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: It will open the gate to your fame.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Here's centaur has immortalised herself, with taming of her wild male.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Ay, she has done the miracle of the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But ladies, do you count it lawful to have such plurality of servants, and do 'em all graces?

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Why not? why should women deny their favours to men? Are they the poorer, or the worse?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Is the Thames the less for the dyers water, mistress?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Or a torch, for lighting many torches?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well said, la-foole; what a new one he has got!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: They are empty losses, women fear, in this kind.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Besides, ladies should be mindful of the approach of age, and let no time want his due use. The best of our days pass first.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: We are rivers, that cannot be called back, madam: she that now excludes her lovers, may live to lie a forsaken beldame, in a frozen bed.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Mavis: and who will wait on us to coach then? or write, or tell us the news then? Make anagrams of our names, and invite us to the cockpit, and kiss our hands all the playtime, and draw their weapons for our honours?

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Not one.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Nay, my mistress is not altogether unintelligent of these things; here be in presence have tasted of her favours.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a neighing hobby-horse is this!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But not with intent to boast 'em again, servant. And have you those excellent receipts, madam, to keep yourselves from bearing of children?

div.p: Now to comfort a poor gentlewoman? Ay me! what fortune had I to marry a distracted man?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I'll tell you, mistress —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How rarely she holds it up!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What mean you, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What will you tell me, servant?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: The disease in Greek, is called Mayia, in Latin, insania, furor, vel ecstasis melancholica, that is, egressio, when a man ex melancholico, evadit fanaticus.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Shall I have a lecture read upon me alive?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: But he may be but Phreneticus, yet, mistress? and phrenetis is only delirium, or so —

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Ay, that is for the disease, servant: but what is this to the cure? we are sure enough of the disease.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let me go.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, we'll entreat her to hold her peace, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, no. Labour not to stop her. She is like a conduit-pipe, that will gush out with more force, when she opens again.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: I'll tell you, Morose, you must talk divinity to her altogether, or moral philosophy.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Ay, and there's an excellent book of moral philosophy, madam, of Raynard the fox, and all the beasts, called Dones philosophy.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: There is, indeed, sir amorous la-foole.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O misery!

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I have read it, my lady centaur, all over to my cousin, hers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Ay, and 'tis a very good book as any is, of the moderns.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Tut, he must have Seneca read to him, and Plutarch, and the ancients; the moderns are not for this disease.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, you discommended them too, today, sir John

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Ay, in some cases: but in these they are best, and Aristotle's ethics.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Say you so, sir John? I think you are deceived: you took it upon trust.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Where's trusty, my woman? I'll end this difference. I pray thee, Otter, call her. Her father and mother were both mad, when they put her to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I think so. Nay, gentlemen, I am tame. This is but an exercise, I know a marriage ceremony, which I must endure.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: And one of 'em (I know not which) was cured with the sick-man's salve; and the other with Greene's groatsworth of wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A very cheap cure, madam.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Ay, it's very feasible.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: My lady called for you, mistress trusty: you must decide a controversy.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: O trusty, which was it you said, your father, or your mother, that was cured with the sick-man's salve?

sp.speaker: Trus.
sp.p: My mother, madam, with the salve.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Then it was the sick-woman's salve.

sp.speaker: Trus.
sp.p: And my father with the groatsworth of wit. But there was other means used: we had a preacher that would preach folk asleep still; and so they were prescribed to go to church, by an old woman that was their physician, thrice a week —

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: To sleep?

sp.speaker: Trus.
sp.p: Yes forsooth: and every night they read themselves asleep on those books.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Good faith, it stands with great reason. I would I knew where to procure those books.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I can help you with one of 'em, mistress Morose, the groatsworth of wit.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But I shall disfurnish you, sir amorous: can you spare it?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: O, yes, for a week, or so; I'll read it myself to him.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, I must do that, sir: that must be my office.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Sure, he would do well enough, if he could sleep.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, I should do well enough, if you could sleep. Have I no friend that will make her drunk? or give her a little laudanum? or opium?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, sir, she talks ten times worse in her sleep.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do you not know that, sir? never ceases all night.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And snores like a porpoise.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, redeem me, fate, redeem me, fate. For how how many causes may a man be divorced, nephew?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I know not truly, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Some divine must resolve you in that, sir, or canon lawyer.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will not rest, I will not think of any other hope or comfort till I know.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas, poor man.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You'll make him mad indeed, ladies, if you pursue this.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: No, we'll let him breathe, now a quarter of an hour, or so.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: By my faith, a large truce.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Is that his keeper, that is gone with him?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: It is his nephew, madam.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Sir Dauphine, Eugenie.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He looks like a very pitiful knight —

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As can be. This marriage, has put him out of all.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: He has not a penny in his purse, madam —

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: He is ready to cry all this day.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: A very shark, he set me i'the nick tother night at primero.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How these swabbers talk!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ay, otters wine has swelled their humours above a springtide.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Good Morose, let's go in again. I like your couches exceeding well: we'll go lie, and talk there.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I wait on you, madam.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Slight, I will have 'em as silent as signs, and their posts too, ere I ha' done. Do you hear, lady-bride? I pray thee now, as thou art a noble wench, continue this discourse of Dauphine within: but praise him exceedingly. Magnify him with all the height of affection thou canst. (I have some purpose in't) and but beat off these two rooks, Jack daw, and his fellow, with any discontentment hither, and I'll honour thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I was about it, here. It angered me to the soul, to hear 'em begin to talk so malepert.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Pray thee perform it, and thou winnest me an idolater to thee, everlasting.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Will you go in, and hear me do it?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, I'll stay here. Drive 'em out of your company, 'tis all I ask: which cannot be any way better done, then by extolling Dauphine, whom they have so slighted.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I warrant you: you shall expect one of 'em presently.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a cast of kestrels are these, to hawk after ladies, thus?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, and strike at such an eagle as Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He will be mad, when we will tell him. Here he comes.
O sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Where's thine uncle?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Run out o'doores in's nightcaps, to talk with a casuist, about his divorce. It works admirably.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou wouldst ha' said so, and thou hadst been here! The ladies have laughed at thee, most comically, since thou wentest, Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And asked, if thou wert thine uncle's keeper?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And the brace of baboons answered, yes; and said, thou wert a pitiful poor fellow, and didst live upon posts: and hadst nothing but three suits of apparel, and some few benevolences that lords ga' thee to fool to hem, and swagger.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Let me not live, I'll beat 'em. I'll bind 'em both to grand madam's bed. posts, and have 'em baited with monkeys.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou shalt not need, they shall be beaten to thy hand, Dauphine. I have an execution to serve upon 'em, I warrant thee shall serve: trust my plot.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Ay, you have many plots! So you had one, to make all the wenches in love with me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, if I do not yet afore night, as near as 'tis; and that they do not every one invite thee, and be ready to scratch for thee: take the mortgage of my wit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Before God, I'll be his witness; thou shalt have it, Dauphine: thou shalt be his fool for ever, if thou dost not.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Agreed. Perhaps 'twill be the better estate. Do you observe this gallery? or rather lobby, indeed? Here are a couple of studies, at each end one: here will I act such a tragicomedy between the Cuelphes, and the Ghibellines,
daw and la-foole — which of 'em comes out first, will I seize on: (You two shall be the chorus behind the arras, and whip out between the acts, and speak.) If I do not make 'em keep the peace, for this remnant of the day, if not of the year, I have failed once — I hear Daw coming: hide, and do not laugh, for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Which is the way into the garden, trow?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, Jack Daw! I am glad I have met with you. In good faith, I must have this matter go no further between you. I must ha' it taken up.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What matter, sir? Between whom?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Come, you disguise it — sir amorous and you. If you love me, Jack, you shall make use of your philosophy now, for this once, and deliver me your sword. This is not the wedding the centaurs were at, though there be a she-one here. The bride has entreated me I will see no blood shed at her bridal, you saw her whisper me erewhile.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As I hope to finish Tacitus, I intend no murder.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Do you not wait for sir amorous?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not I, by my knighthood.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And your scholarship too?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: And my scholarship too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Go to, than I return you your sword, and ask you mercy; but put it not up, for you will be assaulted. I understood that you had apprehended it, and walked here to brave him: and that you had held your life contemptible, in regard of your honour.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: No, no, no such thing I assure you. He and I parted now, as good friends as could be.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Trust not you to that visor. I saw him since dinner with another face: I have known many men in my time vexed with losses, with deaths, and with abuses, but so offended a wight as sir amorous, did I never see, or read of. For taking away his guests, sir, today, that's the cause: and he declares it behind your back; with such threatenings and contempts — he said to Dauphine, you were the arrant'st ass —

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Ay, he may say his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And swears you are so protested a coward, that he knows you will never do him any manly or single right, and therefore he will take his course.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I'll give him any satisfaction, sir — but fighting.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, sir, but who knows what satisfaction he'll take? blood he thirsts for, and blood he will have: and whereabouts on you he will have it, who knows but himself?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I pray you, master tru-wit, be you a mediator.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He puts him up.well, sir, conceal yourself then in this study, till I return. Nay, you must be content to be locked in: for, for mine own reputation I would not have you seen to receive a public disgrace, while I have the matter in managing. God's so, here he comes: keep your breath close, that he do not hear you sigh. In good faith, sir amorous, he is not this way, I pray you be merciful, do not murder him; he is a christian as good as you: you are armed as if you sought a revenge on all his race. Good Dauphine, get him away from this place. I never knew a man's choler so high, but he would speak to his friends, he would hear reason. Jack daw, Jack Daw! asleep?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Is he gone, master tru-wit?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, did you hear him?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O God, yes.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What a quick ear fear has?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: But is he so armed, as you say?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Armed? did you ever see a fellow, set out to take possession?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That may give you some light, to conceive of him: but 'tis nothing to the principal. Some false brother i'the house has furnished him strangely. Or, if it were out of the house, it was Tom Otter.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Indeed, he's a captain, and his wife is his kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He has got somebody's old two-hand-sword to mow you off at the knees. And that sword hath spawned such a dagger! — but then he is so hung with pikes, halberds, peitro●ells, calivers, and muskets, that he looks like a justice of peace's hall: a man of two thousand a year, is not 'sessed at so many weapons, as he has on. There was never fencer challenged at so many several foils. You would think he meant to murder all saint pulehres parish. If he could but victual himself for half a year, in his breeches, he is sufficiently armed to overrun a country.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Good lord, what means he, sir! I pray you master tru-wit, be you a mediator?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, I'll try if he will be appeased with a leg or an arm, if not you must die once.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I would be loath to lose my right arm, for writing madrigals.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, if he will be satisfied with a thumb, or a little finger, all's one to me. You must think, I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Good sir, do.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He puts him up again, and then came forth.what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He will let me do nothing, man, he does all afore me, he offers his left arm.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: His left wing, for a Jack daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Take it, by all means.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How! Maim a man for ever, for a jest? what a conscience hast thou?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: 'Tis no loss to him: he has no employment for his arms, but to eat spoon-meat. Beside, as goods maim his body as his reputation.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He is a scholar, and a wit, and yet he does not think so. But he loses no reputation with us, for we all resolved him an ass before. To your places again.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I pray thee, let me be in at the other a little.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Look, you'll spoil all: these be ever your tricks.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, but I could hit of somethings that thou wilt miss, and thou wilt say are good ones.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I warrant you. I pray forbear, I'll leave it off, else.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Come away, Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir amorous!

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Master tru-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Whither were you going?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Down into the court, to make water.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By no means, sir, you shall rather tempt your breeches.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Why, sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Enter here, if you love your life.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Why! why!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Question till your throat be cut, do: dally till the enraged soul find you.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Daw it is: will you in?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'll in: what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, if he had been cool enough to tell us that, there had been some hope to atone you, but he seems so implacably enraged.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: 'Slight, let him rage. I'll hide myself.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Do, good sir. But what have you done to him within, that should provoke him thus? you have broke some jest upon him, afore the ladies —

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Not I, never in my life, broke jest upon any man. The bride was praising sir Dauphine, and he went away in snuff, and I followed him, unless he took offence at me, in his drink ere while, that I would not pledge all the horse full.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By my faith, and that may be, you remember well: but he walks the round up and down, through every room o'the house, with a towel in his hand, crying, where's la-foole? who saw la-foole? and when Dauphine, and I, demanded the cause, we can force no answer from him, but (O revenge, how sweet art thou! I will strangle him in this towel) which leads us to conjecture, that the main cause of his fury is for bringing your meat today, with a towel about you, to his discredit.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Like enough. Why, and he be angry for that. I'll stay here, till his anger be blown over.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A good becoming resolution, sir. If you can put it on of the sudden.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Yes, I can put it on. Or, I'll away into the country presently.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How will you get out o'the house, sir? He knows you are i' the house, and he'll watch you this seven-night but he'll have you. He'll out-wait a sergeant for you.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Why, then I'll stay here.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You must think, how to victual yourself in time, then.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Why, sweet master tru-wit, will you entreat my cousin Otter, to send me a cold venison pastry, a bottle or two of wine, and a chamber pot.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A stool were better, sir, of sir ajax his invention.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Ay, that will be better indeed: and a palate to lie on.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, I would not advise you to sleep by any means.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Would you not, sir? why, than I will not.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yet, there's another fear —

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Is there, sir? What is't?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, he cannot break open this door with his foot, sure.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I'll set my back against it, sir. I have a good back.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But, than if he should batter.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Batter! if he dare, I'll have an action of battery, against him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Cast you the worst. He has sent for powder already, and what he will do with it, no man knows: perhaps blow up the corner o'the house where he suspects you are. Here he comes, in quickly. I protest, sir John daw,He feigns as if one were present, to fright the other, who is run in to hide himself.he is not this way: what will you do? before God, you shall hang no petard de here. I'll die rather will you not take my word? I never knew one but would be satisfied. Sir amorous, there's no standing out. He has made a petard of an old brass pot, to force your door. Think upon some satisfaction or terms, to offer him.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Sir, I'll give him any satisfaction. I dare give any terms.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You'll leave it to me, then?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Ay, sir. I'll stand to any conditions.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He calls forth Clerimont, and Dauphine.how now, what think you, sirs? were't not a difficult thing to determine, which of these two feared most.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, but this fears the bravest: the other a whiniling dastard, Jack daw: but la-foole, a brave heroic coward! and is afraid in a great look, and a stout accent. I like him rarely.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Had it not been pity, these two should ha' been concealed?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Shall I make a motion?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Briefly. For I must strike while 'tis hot.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Shall I go fetch the ladies to the catastrophe?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Umh? Ay, by my troth.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: By no mortal means. Let them continue in the state of ignorance, and err still: think 'em wits, and fine fellows, as they have done. 'twere sin to reform them.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, i will have 'em fetched, now I think on't, for a private purpose of mine: do, Clerimont, fetch 'em, and discourse to 'em all that's past, and bring 'em into the gallery here.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: This is thy extreme vanity, now: thou think'st thou wert undone, if every jest thou mak'st were not published.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou shalt see, how unjust thou art, presently. Clerimont, say it was Dauphine's plot. Trust me not, if the whole drift be not for thy good. There's a carpet i' the next room, put it on, with this scarf over thy face, and a cushion of thy head, and be ready when I call amorous. Away —. John daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What good news, sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Faith, I have followed, and argued with him hard for you. I told him, you were a knight, and a scholar; and that you knew fortitude did consist magis patiendo quam faciendo, magis ferendo quam feriendo.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: It doth so indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And that you would suffer, I told him: so, at first he demanded, by my troth, in my conceit, too much.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What was it, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your upper lip, and six of your foreteeth.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: 'Twas unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, I told him plainly, you could not spare 'em all. So after long argument (Pro and con, as you know) I brought him down to your two butter-teeth, and them he would have.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, did you so? why, he shall have 'em.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But he shall not, sir, by your leave. The conclusion is this, sir, because you shall be very good friends hereafter, and this never to be remembered, or upbraided; besides, that he may not boast, he has done any such thing to you in his own person: he is to come here in disguise, give you five kicks in private, sir, take your sword from you, and lock you up in that study, during pleasure. Which will be but a little while, we'll get it released presently.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Five kicks? he shall have six, sir, to be friends.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Believe me, you shall not overshoot yourself, to send him that word by me.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Deliver it, sir. He shall have it with all my heart, to be friends.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Friends? Nay, and he should not be so, and heartily too, upon these terms, he shall have me to enemy while I live. Come, sir, bear it bravely.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O God, sir, 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: True. What's six kicks to a man, that reads Seneca?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I have had a hundred, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir amorous. No speaking one to another,Dauphine comes forth, and kicks him.or rehearsing old matters.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: One, two, three, four, five. I protest, sir amorous, you shall have six.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Nay, I told you should not talk. Come give him six, and he will needs. Your sword. Now return to your safe custody: you shall presently meet afore the ladies, and be
the dearest friends one to another — give me the scarf, now, thou shalt beat the other barefaced. Stand by, sir amorous.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: What's here? A sword.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I cannot help it, without I should take the quarrel upon myself: here he has sent you his sword —

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I ll receive none on't.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And he wills you to fasten it against a wall, and break your head in some few several places against the hilts.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I will not: tell him roundly. I cannot endure to shed my own blood.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Will you not?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No. I ll beat it against a fair flat wall, if that will satisfy him: if not, he shall beat it himself, for amorous.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, this is strange starting off, when a man undertakes for you! I offered him another condition: will you stand to that?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Yes, I am content, at the blunt.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Then you must submit yourself to be hoodwinked in this scarce, and be led to him, where he will take your sword from you, and make you bear a blow, over the mouth, gules, and tweaks by the nose, sans numbered.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I am content. But why must I be blinded?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That's for your good, sir: because, if he should grow insolent upon this, and publish it hereafter to your disgrace (Which I hope he will not do) you might swear safely and protest, he never beat you to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: O, I conceive.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I do not doubt, but you'll be perfect good friends upon't, and not dare to utter an ill thought one of another, in future.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Not I, as God help me, of him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nor he of you, sir. If he should — come, sir. All hid, sir John.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: O, sir John, sir John. Dauphine enters to tweak him,o, ô-ô o o o o —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Good sir John, leave tweaking, you'll blow his nose off. 'tis sir John's pleasure, you should retire into the study. Why, now you are friends. All bitterness between you, I hope, is buried; you shall come forth by and by, Damon and Pythias upon't: and embrace with all the rankness of friendship that can be. I trust, we shall have 'em tamer i'their language hereafter. Dauphine, I worship thee. God's will, the ladies have surprised us!

div.head: Act iv. Scene vi.
div.stage: Having discovered part of the past scene above:
Haughty, centaur, Mavis, mistress Otter, Epicoene, Trusty, Dauphine, Tru-wit, etc.

sp.p: Centaur, how our judgements were imposed on by these adulterate knights!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Nay, madam, Mavis was more deceived than we, 'twas her commendation uttered 'em in the college.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I commended but their wits, madam, and their braveries. I never looked towards their valours.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Sir Dauphine is valiant, and a wit too, it seems.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And a bravery too.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Was this his project?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: So master Clerimont intimates, madam.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Good Morose, when you come to the college, will you bring him with you? He seems a very perfect gentleman.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: He is so madam, believe it.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: But when will you come, Morose?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Three or four days hence, madam, when I have got me a coach, and horses.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: No, tomorrow, good Morose, centaur shall send you her coach.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Yes faith, do, and bring sir Dauphine with you.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: She has promised that Mavis.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: He is a very worthy gentleman, in his exteriors, madam.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Ay, he shows he is judicial in his clothes.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And yet not so superlatively neat as some, madam, that have their faces set in a brake!

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Ay, and have every hair in form!

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: That wear purer linen than ourselves, and profess more neatness, than the French hermaphrodite!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I ladies, they, what they tell one of us, have told a thousand, and are the only thieves of our fame: that think to take us with that perfume, or with that lace, and laugh at us unconscionably when they have done.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: But, sir Dauphine's carelessness becomes him.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: I could love a man, for such a nose!

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Or such a leg!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He has an exceeding good eye, madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And a very good lock!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Good Morose, bring him to my chamber first.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Please your honours, to meet at my house, madam?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: See, how they eye thee, man! they are taken I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: You have unbraced our brace of knights, here, master tru-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Not I, madam, it was sir Dauphine's engineer: who, if he have disfurnished your ladyship of any guard, or service by it, is able to make the place good again, in himself.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: There's no suspicion of that, sir.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: God so, Mavis, haughty is kissing.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Let us go too, and take part.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: But I am glad of the fortune (Beside the discovery of two such empty caskets) to gain the knowledge of so rich a mine of virtue, as sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: We would be all glad to style him of our friendship, and see him at the college.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: He cannot mix with a sweeter society, I'll prophesy, and I hope he himself will think so.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I should be rude to imagine otherwise, lady.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee, Dauphine? Why, all their actions are governed by crude opinion, without reason or cause; they know not why they do any thing: but as they are informed, believe, judge, praise, condemn, love, hate, and in emulation one of another, do all these things alike. Only, they have a natural inclination sways 'em generally to the worst, when they are left to themselves. But, pursue it, now thou hast 'em.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Shall we go in again, Morose?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: We'll entreat sir Dauphine's company.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Stay, good madam, the interview of the two friends, Pylades and Orestes: I'll fetch 'em out to you straight.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Will you, master tru-wit?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Ay, but noble ladies, do not confess in your countenance, or outward bearing to 'em any discovery of their follies, that we may see, how they will bear up again, with what assurance, and erection.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: We will not, sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Mau. Upon our honours, sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir amorous, sir amorous. The ladies are here.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Are they?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, but slip out by and by, as their backs are turned, and meet sir John here, as by chance, when I call you. Jack daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What say you, sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Whip out behind me suddenly: and no anger i' your looks to your adversary. Now, now.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Noble sir John Daw! where ha' you been?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: To seek you, sir amorous.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Me! I honour you.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I prevent you ▪ sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: They have forgotten their rapiers!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, they meet in peace, man.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Where's your sword, sir John?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And yours, sir amorous?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Mine! my boy had it forth, to mend the handle, cene now.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: And my gold handle was broke too, and my boy had it forth.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Indeed, sir? How their excuses meet!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a consent there is, i' the handles?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, there is so i' the points too, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O me! Madam, he comes again, the mad man, away.
He had sound the two swords drawn within.what make these naked weapons here, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, sir! here hath like to been murder since you went! A couple of knights fallen out about the bride's favours: we were fain to take away their weapons, your house had been begged by this time else —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: For man slaughter, sir, as being accessary.

sp.speaker: Mor,
sp.p: And, for her favours?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Ay, sir, heretofore, not present. Clerimont, carry 'em their swords, now. They have done all the hurt they will do.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Have you spoke with a lawyer, sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
O, no! there is such a noise i' the court, that they have frighted me home, with more violence than I went! such speaking, and counter-speaking, with their several voices of citations, appellations, allegations, certificates,
attachments, intergatories, references, convictions, and afflictions indeed, among the doctors and proctors! that the noise here is silence to't! A kind of midnight!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, sir, if you would be resolved indeed, I can bring you hither a very sufficient lawyer, and a learned divine, that shall inquire into every least scruple for you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Can you master tru-wit?
Yes, and are very sober grave persons, that will dispatch it in a chamber, with a whisper, or two.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Good sir, shall I hope this benefit from you, and trust myself into your hands?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Alas, sir! your nephew, and I, have been ashamed, and oft-times mad since you went, to think how you are abused. Go in, good sir, and lock yourself up till we call you, we'll tell you more anon, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Do your pleasure with me, gentlemen; I believe in you: and that deserves no delusion —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You shall find none, sir: but heaped, heaped plenty of vexation.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What wilt thou do now, wit?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Recover me hither otter, and the barber if you can, by any means, presently.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why? to what purpose?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, I'll make the deepest divine, and gravest lawyer, out of them two, for him —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Thou canst not man, these are waking dreams.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Do not fear me. Clap but a civil gown with a welt, of the one; and a canonical cloak with sleeves, of the other: and give 'em a few terms i' their mouths, if there come not forth as able a doctor, and complete a parson, for this turn, as may be wished, trust not my election. And, I hope without wronging the dignity of either profession, since they are but persons put on, and for mirth's sake, to torment him. The barber smatters Latin, I remember.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes, and otter too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well then, if I make 'em not wrangle out this case, to his no comfort, let me be thought a lack daw, or la-foole, or any thing worse, go you to your ladies, but first send for them.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I will.
Where had you our swords, master Clerimont?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, Dauphine took 'em from the madman.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: And he took 'em from our boys, I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Very like, sir.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Thank you good master Clerimont. Sir John daw, and I are both beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Would I knew how to make you so, gentlemen:

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Sir amorous, and I are your servants, sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Gentlemen, have any of you a pen-and-ink. I would fain write out a riddle in Italian, for sir Dauphine, to translate.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not I, in troth lady, I am no scrivener.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I can furnish you, I think, lady.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He has it in the haft of a knife, I believe!

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No, he has his box of instruments.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Like a surgeon!

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: For the mathematics: his squire, his compasses, his brass pens, and black-lead, to draw maps of every place, and person, where he comes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How, maps of persons!

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Yes, sir, of Nomentack, when he was here, and of the prince of Moldavia, and of mistress, mistress Epicane.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Away! he has not found our her latitude, I hope.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: You are a pleasant gentleman, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Faith, now we are in private, let's wanton it a little, and talk waggishly. Sir John, I am telling sir amorous here, that you two govern the ladies, where'er you come. you carry the feminine gender afore you.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: They shall rather carry us afore them, if they will, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, I believe that they do, withal — but, that you are the prime-men in their affections, and direct all their actions —

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not I: sir amorous is.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I protest, sir John is.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As I hope to rise i' the state, sir amorous, you ha' the person.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Sir John, you ha' the person, and the discourse too.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not I, sir. I have no discourse — and then you have activity beside.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I protest, sir John, you come as high from Tripoli, as I do every whit: and lift as many joined stools, and leap over 'em, if you would use it —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, agree on't together knights; for between you, you divide the kingdom, or commonwealth of ladies' affections: I see it, and can perceive a little how they observe you, and fear you, indeed. You could tell strange storeys, my masters, if you would, I know.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Faith, we have seen somewhat, sir.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: That we have — velvet petticoats, and wrought smocks, or so.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Ay, and —
Nay, out with it, sir John: do not envy your friend the pleasure of hearing, when you have had the delight of tasting.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Why — a — do you speak, sir amorous.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No, do you, sir John daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I'faith, you shall.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I'faith, you shall.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Why, we have been —

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: In the great bed at Ware together in our time. On, sir John.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Nay, do you, sir amorous.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And these ladies with you, knights?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No, excuse us, sir.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: We must not wound reputation.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: No matter — they were these, or others. Our bath cost us fifteen pound, when we came home.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do you hear, sir John, you shall tell me but one thing truly, as you love me.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: If I can, I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You lay in the same house with the bride, here?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes, and conversed with her hourly, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And what humour is she of? is she coming, and open, free?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, exceeding open, sir. I was her servant, and sir amorous was to be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Come, you have both had favours from her? I know, and have heard so much.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, no, sir.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: You shall excuse us, sir: we must not wound reputation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Tut, she is married, now; and you cannot hurt her with any report, and therefore speak plainly: how many times, i'faith? which of you lead first? Ha?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Sir John had her maidenhead, indeed.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, it pleases him to say so, sir, but sir amorous knows what's what, as well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Dost thou i'faith, amorous?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: In a manner, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, I commend you lads. Little knows don bride groom of this. Nor shall he, for me.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Hang him, mad ox.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Speak softly: here comes his nephew, with the lady haughty. He'll get the ladies from you, sirs, if you look not to him in time.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Why, if he do, we'll fetch 'em home again, I warrant you.

I assure you, sir Dauphine, it is the price and estimation of your virtue only, that hath embarked me to this adventure, and I could not but make out to tell you; nor can I repent me of the act, since it is always an argument of some virtue in ourselves, that we love and affect it so in others.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Your ladyship sets too high a price, on my weakness.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Sir, I can distinguish gems from pebbles —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: (Are you so skilful in stones?)

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: And, howsoever I may suffer in such a judgement as yours, by admitting equality of rank, or society, with centaur or Mavis —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You do not, madam, I perceive they are your mere foils.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Then are you a friend to truth, sir. It makes me love you the more. It is not the outward, but the inward man that I affect. They are not apprehensive of an eminent perfection, but love flat, and dully.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Where are you, my lady haughty.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: I come presently, Centawe. My chamber, sir, my page shall show you; and trusty, my woman, shall be ever a wake for you: you need not fear to communicate any thing with her, for she is a Fidelia. I pray you wear this jewel for my sake, sir Dauphine. Where's Mavis, centaur?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Within, madam, a writing. I'll follow you presently. I'll but speak a word with sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: With me, madam?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Good sir Dauphine, do not trust haughty, nor make any credit to her, whatever you do besides. Sir Dauphine, I give you this caution, she is a perfect courtier; and loves nobody , but for her uses: and for her uses, she loves all. Besides, her physicians give her out to be none o'the clearest, whether she pay 'em or no, heaven knows: and she's abode fifty too, and pargets! See her in a forenoon. Here comes Mavis, a worse face than she! you would not like this, by candlelight. If you'll come to my chamber one of these mornings early, or late in an evening, I'll tell you more. Where's haughty, Mavis?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Within, centaur.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: What ha' you, there?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: An Italian riddle for sir Dauphine, (You shall not see it i'faith, centaur.) Good sir Dauphine, solve it for me. I'll call for it anon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How now, Dauphine? how dost thou quit thyself of these females?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: 'Slight, they haunt me like fairies, and give me jewels here, I cannot be rid of 'em,

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: O, you must not tell, though.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Mass, I forgotten that: I was never so assaulted. One loves for virtue, and bribes me with this. Another loves me with caution, and so would possess me. A third brings me a riddle here, and all are jealous: and rail each at other.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He reads the paper.a riddle? pray le' me see't? Sir Dauphine, I chose this way of intimation for privacy. The ladies here, I know, have both hope, and purpose, to make a collegiate and servant of you. If I might be so honoured, as to appear at any end of so noble a work, I would enter into a fame of taking physic tomorrow, and continue you it four or five days, or longer, for your visitation. Mavis. By my faith, a subtle one! Call you this a riddle? What's their plain dealing, trow?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: We lack tru-wit, to tell us that.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: We lack him for somewhat else too: his knights reformados are wound up as high, and insolent, as ever they were.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You jest.

sp.speaker: Cle,
sp.p: No drunkards, either with wine or vanity, ever confessed such storeys of themselves. I would not give a fly's leg, in ballance against all the women's reputations here, if they could be but thought to speak truth: and, for the bride, they have made their affidavit against her directly —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What, they have lyen with her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, and tell times, and circumstances, with the cause why, and the place where. I had almost brought 'em to affirm that they had done it, today.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Not both of 'em.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes faith: with a sooth or two more I had effected it. They would ha' set it down under their hands.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why, they will be our sport, I see, still! whether we will, or no.

div.head: Act v. scene iii.
div.stage: Tru-wit, Morose, Otter, Cutberd, Clerimont, Dauphine.

sp.p:
O, are you here? Come Dauphine, go call your uncle presently. I have fitted my divine, and my canonist, died their beards and all: the knaves do not know themselves they are so exalted, and altered. Preferment changes any man. Thou shalt keep one door, and I another, and then Clerimont in the midst, that he may have no means of escape from their cavilling, when they grow hot once again. And then the women (As I have given the bride her instructions) to break in upon him, i' the l'envoy. O, 'twill be full and twanging! Away, fetch him. Come, master doctor, and master parson, look to your parts now, and discharge 'em bravely: you are well set forth, perform
it as well. If you chance to be out, do not confess it with standing still, or humming, or gaping one at another: but go on, and talk aloud, and eagerly, use vehement action, and only remember your terms, and you are safe. Let the matter go where it will: you have many will do so. But at first, be very solemn, and grave like your garments, though you lose yourselves after, and skip out like a brace of jugglers on a table. Here he comes! set your faces, and look superciliously, while I present you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Are these the two learned men?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, sir, please you salute 'em?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Salute 'em? I had rather do any thing, then wear out time so unfruitfully, sir. I wonder, how these common forms, as God save you, and you are welcome, are come to be a habit in our lives! or, I am glad to see you! when I cannot see, what the profit can be of these words, so long as it is no whit better with him, whose affairs are sad, and grievous, that he hears this salutation.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Tis true, sir, we'll go to the matter then. Gentlemen, master doctor, and master parson, I have acquainted you sufficiently with the business, for which you are come hither. And you are not now to inform yourselves in the state of the question, I know. This is the gentleman, who expects your resolution, and therefore, when you please, begin.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Please you, master doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Please you, good master parson.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I would hear the canon law speak first.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: It must give place to positive divinity, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Nay, good gentlemen, do not throw me into circumstances. Let your comforts arrive quickly at me, those that are. Be swift in affording me my peace, if so I shall hope any. I love not your dispurations, or your court-tumults. And that it be not strange to you, I will tell you. My father, in my education, was wont to advise me, that I should always collect, and contain my mind, not suffering
it to flow loosely; that I should look to what things were necessary to the carriage of my life, and what not: embracing the one and eschewing the other. In short, that I should endear myself to rest, and avoid turmoil: which now is grown to be another nature to me. So that I come not to your public pleadings, or your places of noise; not that I neglect those things, that make for the dignity of the commonwealth: but for the mere avoiding of clamours, and impertinences of orators, that know not how to be silent. And for the cause of noise, am I now a suitor to you you do not know in what a misery I have been exercised this day, what a torrent of evil! My very house turns round with the tumult! I dwell in a windmill! The perpetual about motion is here, and not at Eltham.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, good master doctor, will you break the ice? Master parson will wade after.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Sir, though unworthy, and the weaker, I will presume.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: 'Tis no presumption, dominae doctor.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yet again!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Your question is, for how many causes a man may have divortium legitimum, a lawful divorce. First, you must understand the nature of the word divorce, a divertendo —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No excursions upon words, good doctor, to the question briefly.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I answer then, the canon-law affords divorce but in few cases, and the principal is in the common case, the adulterous case. But there are dvodecim impedimenta, twelve impediments (As we call 'em) all which do not dirimere contractum, but irritum reddere matrimonium, as we say in the canon-law, not take away the bond, but cause a nullity therein.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I understood you, before: good sir, avoid your impertinency of translation.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: He cannot open this too much, sir, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yet more!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, you must give the learned men leave, sir. To your impediments, master doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The first is impedimentum erroris.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Of which there are several species.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Ay, as error personae.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If you contract yourself to one person, thinking her another.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Then, error fortunae.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If she be a beggar, and you thought her rich.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Then, error qualitatis.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If she prove stubborn, or headstrong, that you thought obedient.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How? is that, sir, a lawful impediment? One at once, I pray you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Ay, ante copulam, but not post copulam, sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Master parson says right. Nec post nuptiarum benedictionem. It doth indeed but irrita reddere sponsalia, annul the contract: after marriage it is of no obstancy.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Alas, sir, what a hope are we fallen from, by this time!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The next is conditio: if you thought her free born, and she prove a bondwoman, there is impediment of estate and condition.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Ay, but master doctor, those servitudes are subla●●e, now, among us Christians.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: By your favour, master parson —

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You shall give me leave, master doctor.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, quarrel not in that question; it concerns not my case: pass to the third.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Well then, the third is votum. If either party have made a vow of chastity. But that practice, as master parson said of the other, is taken away among us, thanks be to discipline. The fourth is cognatio: if the persons be of kin, within the degrees.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I: do you know, what the degrees are, sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, nor I care not, sir: they offer me no comfort in the question, I am sure,

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: But, there is a branch of this impediment may, which is cognatio spiritualis. If you were her godfather, sir, than the marriage is incestuous.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: That comment is absurd, and superstitious, master doctor. I cannot endure it. Are we not all brothers and sisters, and as much a kin in that, as godfathers, and god-daughters?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O me! to end the controversy, I never was a godfather, I never was a godfather in my life, sir. Pass to the next.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The sift is crimen adulterij: the known case. The sixth, cultus disparitas, difference of religion: have you ever examined her what religion she is of?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, I would rather she were of none, then be put to the trouble of it!

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You may have it done for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By no means, good sir, on to the rest: shall you ever come to an end, think you?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, he has done half, sir. (On, to the rest) be patient, and expect, sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The seventh is, vis: if it were upon compulsion, or force.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O no, it was too voluntary, mine: too voluntary.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The eighth is, ordo: if ever she have taken holy order.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: That's superstitious, too.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No matter, master parson: would she would go into a nunnery yet.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The ninth is, ligamen: if you were bound, sir, to any other before.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I thrust myself too soon into these fetters.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The tenth is, publica honestas: which is inchoata quaedam affinitas.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Ay, or affinitas orta ex sponsalibus: and is but leave impedimentum.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I feel no air of comfort blowing to me, in all this.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The eleventh is, affinitas ex fornication.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Which is no less vera affinitas, than the other master doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: True, quae oritur ex legitimo matrimonio.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You say right, venerable doctor. And, nascitur ex co, quod per coniugium dvae personae efficiuntur una caro —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Heyday, now they begin.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I conceive you, master parson. Ita per fornicationem aeque est verus pater, qui sic generat —

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Et vere filius qui sic generatur —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What's all this to me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now it grows warm.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The twelfth, and last is, si forte coire nequibis.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Ay, that is impedimentum gravissimum. It doth utterly annul, and annihilate, that. If you have manifestam frigiditatem, you are well, sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, there is comfort come at length, sir. Confess yourself but a man unable, and she will sue to be divorced first.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Ay, or if there be morbus perpetuus, et insanabilis, as paralysis, elephantiasis, or so —

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: O, but frigiditas is the fairer way, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You say troth, sir, and as it is in the canon master doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I conceive you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Before he speaks.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: That a boy, or child, under years, is not fit for marriage, because he cannot reddere debitum. So your omnipotentes —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your impotentes, you whoreson lobster.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Your impotentes, I should say, are minime apti ad contrahenda matrimonium.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Matrimonium? We shall have most unmatrimonial Latin, with you: matrimonia, and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Doup.
sp.p: You put 'em out, man.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: But then there will arise a doubt, master parson, in our case, post matrimonium: that frigiditate praeditus (Do you conceive me, sir?)

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Who cannot uti uxore pro uxore, may habere cam pro sorore.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Absurd, absurd, absurd, and merely apostatical.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: You shall pardon me, master parson, I can prove it.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You can prove a will, master doctor, you can prove nothing else. Does not the verse of your own Caxan say, haec socianda vetant connubia, facta retractant —

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I grant you, but how do they retractare, master parson?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: (Oh, this was it, I feared.)

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: In aeternum, sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: That's false in divinity, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: 'Tis false in humanity, to say so. Is he not prorsus inutilis ad thorum? Can he praestare fidem datam? I would fain know.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes: how if he do convalere?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: He cannot connulere, it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, good sir, attend the learned men, they'll think you neglect 'em else.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Or, if he do simulare himself frigidum, odio uxoris, or so?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I say, he is adulter manifestus, then.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: (They dispute it very learnedly, i'faith.)

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And prostitutor uxoris, and this is positive.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Good sir, let me escape.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You will not do me that wrong, sir?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And therefore, if he be manifest frigidus, sir —

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Ay, if he be manifest frigidus, I grant you —

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Why, that was my conclusion.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And mine too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, hear the conclusion, sir.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Then frigiditatis causa —

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes, causa frigiditatis —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, mine ears!

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: She may have libellum divortij, against you.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Ay, divorty libellum she will sure have.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Good echoes, forbear.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If you confess it.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Which I would do, sir —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will do any thing —

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And clear myself in foro conscientiae —

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Because you want indeed —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yet more?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Exercende potestate.

div.head: Act v. scene iiii.
div.stage: Epicoene, Morose, haughty, centaur, Mavis, mistress Otter, Daw, Tru-wit, Dauphine, Clerimont, La-foole, otter, Cutherd.

sp.p: I will not endure it any longer. Ladies, I beseech you help me. This is such a wrong, as never was offered to poor bride before. Upon her marriage day, to have her husband conspire against her, and a couple of mercenary companions, to be brought in for form's sake, to persuade a separation! If you had blood, or virtue in you, gentlemen, you would not suffer such earwigs about a husband, or scorpions, to creep between man and wife —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, the variety, and changes of my torment!

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Let 'em be cudgeled out of doors, by our grooms.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: I'll lend you my footman.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: We'll have our men blanket 'em i'the hall.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: As there was one, at our house, madam, for peeping in at the door.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Content, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Stay, ladies, and gentlemen, you'll hear, before you proceed?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I'd ha' the bridegroom blanketed, too.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Begin with him first.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Yes, by my troth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, mankind generation!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Ladies, for my sake forbear.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Yes, for sir Dauphine's sake.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He shall command us.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: He is as fine a gentleman of his inches, madam, as any is about the town, and wears as good colours when he lift.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Be brief, sir, and confess your infirmity, she'll be afire to be quit of you, if she but hear that named once, you shall not entreat her to stay. She'll fly you, like one that had the marks upon him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ladies, I must crave all your pardons —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Silence, ladies.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: For a wrong I have done to your whole sex, in marrying this fair, and virtuous gentlewoman —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hear him, good ladies.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Being guilty of an infirmity, which before I conferred with these learned men, I thought I might have concealed —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But now being better informed in his conscience by them, he is to declare it, and give satisfaction, by asking your public forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am no man, ladies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How!
