sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Utterly un-abled in nature, by reason of frigidity, to perform the duties, or any the least office of a husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Now, out upon him, prodigious creature!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Bridegroom uncarnate .

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: And would you offer it to a young gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: A lady of her longings?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Tut, a device, a device, this, it smells rankly, ladies. A mere comment of his own.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, if you suspect that, ladies, you may have him searched.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As the custom is, by a jury of physicians.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Yes faith, 'twill be brave.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O me, must I undergo that!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: No, let women search him, madam: we can do it ourselves.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Our on me, worse!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No ladies, you shall not need, I'll take him with all his faults.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Worst of all!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, then 'tis no divorce, doctor, if she consent not?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: No, if the man be frigidus, it is de part uxoris, that we grant libellum divorty, in the law.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Ay, it is the same in theology.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Worse, worse than worst!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, sir, be not utterly disheartened, we have yet a small relic of hope left, as near as our comfort is blown out. Clerimont, produce your brace of knights. What was that, master parson, you told me in errore qualitatis e'en now? Dauphine, whisper the bride, that she carry it as if she were guilty, and ashamed.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Marry sir, in errore qualitatis (Which master doctor did forbear to urge) if she be found corupta, that is, vitiated or broken up, that was pro virgin desponsa, espoused for a maid —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What then, sir?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: It doth dirimere contractum, and irritum reddere too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: If this be true, we are happy again, sir, once more. Here are an honourable brace of knights, that shall affirm so much.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Pardon us, good master Clerimont.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: You shall excuse us, master Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, you must make it good now, knights, there is no remedy, I'll eat no words for you, nor no men: you know you spoke it to me?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Is this gentleman-like-like, sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Jack daw, he's worse than sir amorous: fiercer a great deal. Sir amorous, beware, there be ten daws in this Clerimont.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I'll confess it, sir.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Will you, sir amorous? will you wound reputation?

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: So should you be too, Jack daw: what should keep you off? she is but a woman, and in disgrace. He'll be glad on't.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Will he? I thought he would ha'been angry.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You will dispatch, knights, it must be done, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, an' it must it shall, sir, they say. They'll never go back. Do not tempt his patience.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: It is true indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Yes, I assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is true gentlemen? what do you assure me?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: That we have known your bride, sir —

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: In good fashion. She was our mistress, or so —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, you must be plain, knights, as you were to me.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Ay, the question is, if you have carnaliter, or no.

sp.speaker: La-f.
sp.p: Carnaliter? what else, sir?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: It is enough: a plain nullity.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I am undone, I am undone!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, let me worship and adore you, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I am undone!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, to my hand, I thank these knights: master parson, let me thank you otherwise.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And, ha' they confessed?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Now out upon 'em, informers!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You see, what creatures you may bestow your favours on, madames.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: I would except against 'em as beaten knights, wench, and not good witnesses in law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Poor gentlewoman, how she takes it!

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Be comforted, Morose, I love you the better for't.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: So do I, I protest.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: But gentlemen, you have not known her, since matrimonium?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not today, master doctor.

sp.speaker: La F.
sp.p: No, sir, not today.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why, then I say, for any act before, the matrimonium is good and perfect: unless, the worshipful bridegroom did precisely, before witness demand, if she were virgo ante nuptias.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, that he did not, I assure you, master doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: If he cannot prove that, it is ratum coniugium, notwithstanding the premises. And they do no way impedire. And this is my sentence, this I pronounce.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I am of master doctor's resolution too, sir: if you made not that demand, ante nuptias.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O my heart! wilt thou break? wilt thou break? this is worst of all worst worsts! that hell could have devised! Marry a whore! and so much noise!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Come, I see now plain confederacy in this doctor, and this parson, to abuse a gentleman. You study his affliction. I pray be gone companions. And gentlemen, I begin to suspect you for having parts with 'em. Sir, will it please you hear me?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, do not talk to me, take not from me the pleasure of dying in silence, nephew.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Sir, I must speak to you. I have been long your poor despised kinsman, and many a hard thought has strengthened you against me: but now it shall appear if either I love you or your peace, and prefer them to all the world beside. I will not be long or grievous to you, sir. If I free you of this unhappy match absolutely, and instantly after all this trouble, and almost in your despair, now —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: (It cannot be.)

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p:
Sir, that you be never troubled with a murmur
of it more, what shall I hope for, or deserve of you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, what thou wilt, nephew! thou shalt deserve me, and have me.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Shall I have your favour perfect to me, and love hereafter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: That, and any thing beside. Make thine own conditions. My whole estate is thine. Manage it, I will become thy ward.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Nay, sir, I will not be so unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Will sir Dauphine be mine enemy too?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You know, I have been a long suitor to you, uncle, that out of your estate, which is fifteen hundred a year, you would allow me but five hundred during life, and assure the rest upon me after: to which I have often, by myself and friends tendered you a writing to sign, which you would never consent, or incline too. If you please to effect it now —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Thou shalt have it, nephew. I will do it, and more.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: If I quit you not presently? and forever of this cumber, you shall have power instantly, afore all these, to revoke your act, and I will become, whose slave you will give me to, forever.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Where is the writing? I will seal to it, that, or to a blank, and write thine own conditions.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: O me, most unfortunate wretched gentlewoman!

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.p: Will sir Dauphine do this?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Good sir, have some compassion on me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, my nephew knows you belike: away crocodile.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He does it not sure, without good ground.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Come nephew: give me the pen. I will subscribe to any thing, and seal to what thou wilt, for my deliverance. Thou art my restorer. Here, I deliver it thee as my deed. If there be a word in it lacking, or writ with false orthography, I protest before — I will not take the advantage.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Then here is your release,〈…〉sir: you have married a boy: a gentleman's son, that I have brought up this half year, at my great charges, and for this composition, which I have now made with you. What say you, master doctor? this is iustum impedimentum, I hope, error personae?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Yes sir, in primo gradu.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: In primo graou.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: He pulls off their beards, and disguise.I thank you, good doctor Cutberd, and parson Otter. You are beholden to 'em, sir, that have taken this pains for you: and my friend, master tru-wit, who enabled 'em for the business. Now you may go in and rest, be as private as you will, sir. I'll not trouble you, till you trouble me with your funeral, which I care not how soon it come. Cutberd, I'll make your lease good. Thank me not, but with your leg, Cutberd. And Tom Otter, your Princess shall be reconciled to you. How now, gentlemen! do you look at me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A boy.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes, mistress Epicoene.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Well, Dauphine, you have lurched your friends of the better half of the garland, by concealing this part of the plot: but much good do it thee, thou deservest it, lad. And Clerimont, for thy unexpected bringing in these two to confession, wear my part of it freely. Nay, sir Daw, and sir la-foole, you see the gentlewoman that has done you the favours! we are all thankful to you, and so should the womankind here, specially for lying on her, though not with her! You meant so, I am sure? But, that we have stuck it upon you today, in your own imagined persons, and so lately; this Amazon, the champion of the sex, should beat you now thriftily, for the common slanders, which ladies receive from such cuckoos, as you are. You are they, that when no merit or fortune can make you hope to enjoy their bodies, will yet lie with their reputations, and make their fame suffer. Away you common moths of these, and all ladies' honours, go, travail to make legs and faces,
and come home with some new matter to be laughed at: you deserve to live in an air as corrupted, as that wherewith you feed rumour. Madames, you are mute, upon this new metamorphosis! but here stands she, that has vindicated your fames. Take heed of such insectae hereafter. And let it not trouble you that you have discovered any mysteries to this young gentleman. He is (Almost) of years, and will make a good visitant within this twelvemonth. In the mean time, we'll all undertake for his secrecy, that can speak so well of his silence. Spectators, if you like this comedy, rise cheerfully, and now Morose is gone in, clap your hands. It may be, that noise will cure him, at least please him.
